This patient’s repeated binge-eating episodes, defined as eating in a discrete period an amount of food definitively larger than most individuals would eat in a similar period, along with feeling a lack of control over the eating, is concerning for an eating disorder. Since the patient does not engage in compensatory behaviors such as purging, laxative use, or excessive exercise, and has not lost weight, the most likely diagnosis is binge-eating disorder. Additional supporting features for this diagnosis are the presence of symptoms for several years, feelings of marked distress regarding these episodes, experiencing guilt regarding her binge-eating, and eating until feeling uncomfortably full. 

Patients experiencing Bulimia Nervosa and Anorexia Nervosa, binge-eating/purging type may also present with binge-eating episodes. However, purging behavior must be present for a patient to receive a diagnosis of bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa binge-eating/purging type. Purging behaviors are compensatory actions to avoid weight gain that occurs after binge-eating episodes. Purging behavior can include over-use of laxatives, exercise, avoidance of food, and self-induced emesis (the most common type of purging behavior). Assessing symptoms of malnutrition is the best way to differentiate patients with anorexia nervosa from patients with bulimia nervosa. Patients with Anorexia nervosa will present with signs of malnutrition and a BMI of 18.5 or less. Classic physical exam findings of malnutrition associated with anorexia nervosa are temporal wasting and “lanugo.” 

P.S. If you or someone you know is experiencing an eating disorder, you can call the ANAD National Eating Disorder Helpline at 800.375.7767 or visit https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/get-help/ to learn more about resources available in your area.   

Option Analysis

✅ Binge-eating disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Anorexia nervosa disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with a binge-eating/purging type of anorexia nervosa can present with binge-eating episodes. However, this patient does not have purging behavior after these binge episodes, suggesting that binge-eating disorder is more likely.  
❌ Avoidant restrictive food intake disorder:
Incorrect: Avoidant restrictive food intake disorder can cause nutritional deficiencies, unexplained weight loss, or disordered eating. This patient does not have food avoidance tendencies, weight loss, or evidence of nutritional deficiencies to suggest this disorder. 
❌ Bulimia nervosa disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with bulimia nervosa can present with binge-eating episodes; however, the diagnosis of bulimia nervosa also requires the presence of compensatory behaviors, such as purging, over-use of laxatives, or exercise, which are not present in this patient.  
❌ Rumination disorder:
Incorrect: Rumination disorder is an often-missed form of disordered eating characterized by repeated regurgitation of undigested or partially digested food. This patient does not have the repeated regurgitation of food required to make this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with chronic seizure disorder is brought to the emergency department unresponsive. His neighbor is present and provides history. The patient has taken prescribed phenobarbital for 20 years. Five days ago, he ran out of it while quarantining at home during the COVID-19 pandemic. The patient’s primary care physician reached out to make a virtual appointment to refill this medication, but the patient never showed for the appointment. Over the next five days, the patient developed nausea, vomiting, anxiety, tremors, abdominal cramps, and profuse sweating. This morning the neighbor gave the patient 10 tablets of pentobarbital, which the patient took all at once. Within an hour, the patient began feeling cold, thirsty, light-headed, and lethargic. The neighbor subsequently called emergency medical services. In the emergency department, temperature is 35.8 ºC (96.4 ºF), pulse is 48/min, respirations are 8/min, blood pressure is 82/51, and SpO2 is 90% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has horizontal nystagmus, slurred speech, and is difficult to awaken. After initial stabilization and treatment, which of the following is best for reducing this patient’s long-term dependence on barbiturates?
questions.solution:
This patient is initially suffering from barbiturate withdrawal, due to sudden cessation of phenobarbital. Phenobarbital acts by increasing the duration of gabanergic potentiation, allowing chloride to pass through the channel and creating a postsynaptic inhibitory effect that produces sedation. Whenever possible, barbiturates need to be tapered off to minimize the chances of developing withdrawal and restoring CNS tone. When patients have developed withdrawal, it is imperative to institute a long-term taper with drugs that have gabanergic cross-reactivity. The first line is benzodiazepines due to their wider therapeutic window.       

In the case of this patient, taking high doses of pentobarbital (a more potent barbiturate) caused a barbiturate overdose. Barbiturate overdose occurs quickly and presents as excessive thirst, lightheadedness, confusion, hypotension, and even loss of consciousness/coma. As there is no specific antidote for barbiturate overdose, the mainstays of treatment include supportive care, especially cardiopulmonary support. Flumazenil is not effective in treating barbiturate overdose. Several case studies report activated charcoal as useful in decreasing the half-life of barbiturates and accelerating recovery from overdose.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pentobarbital :
Incorrect: Pentobarbital, like phenobarbital, is a barbiturate. Pentobarbital is more potent than phenobarbital in producing gabanergic potentiation and elevating motor cortical thresholds. Switching this patient to pentobarbital would not treat barbiturate dependence and may cause more harm. 
✅ Benzodiazepines with a gradual taper :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Flumazenil :
Incorrect: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist, which blocks the actions of benzodiazepines and non-benzodiazepine benzodiazepine receptor agonists (NBBRAs). Flumazenil only binds these benzodiazepine-specific sites and does not work for barbiturate overdose or withdrawal.  
❌ Carbamazepine  :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is a sodium channel blocker often used as an anticonvulsant. While it may be an appropriate medication for this patient’s seizure disorder, it has no effect on gabanergic potentiation and thus would not treat barbiturate dependence.  
❌ 12 step program for alcohol use disorder :
Incorrect: Initially, this patient is experiencing symptoms of barbiturate withdrawal followed by a barbiturate overdose. Ethanol (“alcohol”) weakly binds between the alpha and gamma subunits of the GABA receptor and can cause effects similar to benzodiazepines and barbiturates. This patient’s history indicates barbiturate withdrawal, not alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man present to his psychiatrist's office for a scheduled follow-up visit. The patient has a history of schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, that was diagnosed during a recent admission to the local psychiatric inpatient unit. The patient was discharged from the unit on aripiprazole, which he reports adequately controls his psychiatric symptoms. However, he has developed muscle stiffness and intermittent neck spasms on the right and difficulty rotating his head. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 16/minute, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows an adult who appears his stated age and is calm and cooperative. Musculoskeletal exam reveals mild discomfort and muscle spasm at the right neck and limited rotation of the neck during active and passive range of motion testing, The patient’s head stays in a neutral position at rest. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient experiencing neck muscle stiffness and spasms that began shortly after starting an antipsychotic medication is having a dystonic reaction. An anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine or diphenhydramine, is the most appropriate treatment for the acute management of dystonia.

Dystonic reactions (i.e., dyskinesias) are reversible extrapyramidal symptoms that develop shortly after starting medications that block dopamine receptors. Dopamine blockade can cause involuntary muscle contractions, leading to abnormal muscle stiffness and difficulty relaxing the affected muscles. Dystonic reactions range in severity and can include torticollis, oculogyric crisis, and opisthotonos. These reactions are more common with the use of first-generation antipsychotics. However, even second-generation antipsychotics like aripiprazole, which are partial agonists of dopamine receptors, increase the risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.  

Patients with dystonia should be given an anticholinergic medication, like benztropine or diphenhydramine, for symptom management. Patients with mild dystonia may respond well to oral anticholinergic medication, while more severe cases, such as in patients experiencing oculogyric crisis, may require intravenous (IV) or intramuscular (IM) administration. The most effective way to reduce the risk of future dystonic reactions is to switch to an alternative medication with a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.    

Option Analysis

✅ Benztropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is effective for movement disorders such as akathisia or tremor. However, this patient’s recent initiation of aripiprazole and muscle stiffness and spasm is consistent with a dystonic reaction. An anticholinergic medication like benztropine is the appropriate treatment. 
❌ Bromocriptine:
Incorrect: While bromocriptine may help treat certain types of dystonia, an anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine, is a better initial choice for this patient.  
❌ Donepezil :
Incorrect: Donepezil, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is primarily used for treating patients with Alzheimer disease. This patient is experiencing a dystonic reaction from aripiprazole, and an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor could worsen symptoms. An anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine, is the best treatment.  
❌ Valbenazine :
Incorrect: Valbenazine is used to treat tardive dyskinesia, a condition characterized by sudden, involuntary movements of the face or body that can develop months or years after the initiation of antipsychotic therapy. This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with a dystonic reaction, for which an anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine, is appropriate.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes the primary care office for evaluation of difficulty sleeping. The patient reports he has been sleeping only two hours a night for the past two weeks. He says he’s asleep for about two hours and then wakes up feeling well rested and “ready to take on the day.” He has started a new “side-gig” that he is very optimistic about in addition to his full-time job. He feels that he is able to keep up with both jobs and may consider a third. He reports that his work performance has been “excellent,” which has led to a recent raise. He has taken on multiple new hobbies recently, most of which have helped him make new friends. However, he had to dip into some of his savings to pursue these hobbies. He has no significant medical history or psychiatric history and has not had any significant life changes or stressors recently. He does not use stimulants or other recreational or prescribed substances and is drug-tested for his job regularly. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations 20/minute, blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Mental status exam is significant for an extremely talkative patient with a euphoric affect, increased psychomotor activity, and rapid speech. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms and examination findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with a euphoric mood with decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activities, grandiosity, irresponsible behavior, and talkativeness meet criteria for a hypomanic episode, which is suggestive of a diagnosis of bipolar 2 disorder.        

A hypomanic episode is defined as a discrete period of at least four days with the patient experiencing at least three (if elated mood predominates) or four (if irritable mood predominates) of the additional symptoms that characterize mania. There must be an unequivocal change in functioning without leading to social or occupational impairment. This latter criterion is unlike manic episodes, which require functional impairment as part of its diagnostic criteria.        

In patients with symptoms concerning for hypomania, it is important to rule out the use of prescription medications or recreational substances that may cause similar findings, such as stimulant medications or cocaine.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hypomanic episode:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Manic episode :
Incorrect: Manic episodes can present with decreased need for sleep and increased goal-directed activity. However, this patient’s lack of social or occupational impairment is more consistent with a hypomanic episode. 
❌ Cyclothymia:
Incorrect: Cyclothymia is characterized by the combination of episodes of hypomanic or manic symptoms that do not meet criteria for hypomania or mania and episodes of depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for major depressive disorder that have lasted for at least two years. This patient’s symptoms do meet criteria for a hypomanic episode per the DSM-5 TR, and therefore a diagnosis of cyclothymia would not apply. 
❌ Adjustment disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with an adjustment disorder have symptoms that occur in response to a specific stressor. This patient does not report recent life events or changes in life circumstances; therefore, a diagnosis of adjustment disorder would not apply.  
❌ Substance use :
Incorrect: Patients presenting with symptoms concerning mania or hypomania should be assessed for use of stimulants like amphetamines, methylphenidate, cocaine, and methamphetamine. However, this patient reports that he has not recently used recreational or prescribed substances, which is supported by his consistently negative drug tests done at his workplace.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the primary care clinic for evaluation of 3 months of moderate anxiety that has been constant. He has not experienced chest pain or panic attacks but reports erectile dysfunction and premature ejaculation over the same period which he has never experienced before. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows an anxious man who appears his stated age with mild diaphoresis. Dermatological examination reveals thinning hair and moist skin. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 24-year-old patient presents with constant moderate anxiety for three months in addition to new-onset erectile dysfunction and premature ejaculation and physical examination findings of thinning hair, tachycardia, and moist skin. These findings are suggestive of hyperthyroidism. A thyroid panel is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient’s anxiety.        

When evaluating patients with anxiety, it is important to rule out possible medical causes of anxiety before diagnosing a psychiatric disorder. This is important because treating underlying medical conditions may result in resolution or improvement in the anxiety symptoms. Medical conditions that can cause symptoms that are also seen in anxiety disorders include hyperthyroidism, asthma, atrial fibrillation, and neurocognitive disorders like Alzheimer dementia or frontotemporal dementia.       

Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid panel:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Polysomnography :
Incorrect: Untreated sleep apnea can present with anxiety and depression. However, this patient does not have daytime somnolence, snoring, or other signs or symptoms to indicate a need for evaluation for sleep apnea. 
❌ Thyroid ultrasound:
Incorrect: Thyroid ultrasound is an important diagnostic step in the diagnostic workup of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. However, a thyroid panel should be ordered in this patient with signs and symptoms consistent with hyperthyroidism before considering a thyroid ultrasound.  
❌ Psychiatry referral:
Incorrect: While it is reasonable to refer patients with anxiety to psychiatry, this patient has signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism which can be a cause of anxiety. Evaluation for underlying medical causes of his symptoms should be performed before referral to psychiatry.  
❌ Troponins:
Incorrect: Ordering troponins is important to rule out underlying cardiac disease in patients who present with panic attacks with chest pain. However, this patient does not have chest pain.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department for a 3-week history of auditory hallucinations. Earlier in the day, he went to work and was advised by his supervisor to seek hospital evaluation. He describes his hallucinations as green aliens on his shoulders commanding him to harm others. He has no past psychiatric or medical history and does not use recreational substances. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The mental status exam shows a calm male who appears his stated age with disorganized thought processes, a narrow range of affect, and increased latency of response. Urinary drug screen and blood alcohol levels are both negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 33-year-old patient presents with auditory hallucinations, thought blocking (evidenced by increased response latency), a narrow range of affect, and disorganized thought processes — all concerning for psychosis. Given that his symptoms have persisted for three weeks, and he does not have a history of previous psychotic episodes, the most appropriate diagnosis is brief psychotic disorder.         

Schizophrenia spectrum disorders are differentiated based on symptom duration: brief psychotic disorder is diagnosed when symptoms last from one day to one-month, schizophreniform disorder when symptoms last from one to six months, and schizophrenia when symptoms persist for at least six months. When evaluating a patient for a schizophrenia spectrum disorder, it is crucial to rule out stimulant intoxication, as substances like cocaine, phencyclidine (PCP, or “angel dust”), or 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, or “ecstasy”) can also cause symptoms like hallucinations and paranoia.        

Additionally, mood disorders should be considered. Schizoaffective disorder is diagnosed when a patient exhibits both mood disorder symptoms and psychosis, with a history of at least two weeks of psychosis symptoms occurring independently of a mood episode. In contrast, major depressive disorder with psychotic features or bipolar disorder with psychotic features should be considered if psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during a mood episode.    

Option Analysis

✅ Brief psychotic disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Schizophreniform disorder:
Incorrect: Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed when psychotic symptoms are present for one to six months. As this patient's symptoms have lasted for three weeks, brief psychotic disorder is the most appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: Schizophrenia is diagnosed when psychotic symptoms persist for at least six months. Since this patient's symptoms have persisted for 3 weeks, brief psychotic disorder is the most appropriate diagnosis. 
❌ Schizoaffective disorder :
Incorrect: Schizoaffective disorder is diagnosed when patients experience both mood disorder symptoms and psychosis, with a history of at least a 2-week period of psychotic symptoms occurring independently of a mood episode. As this patient’s symptoms are new, and he does not have a prior history suggestive of a mood disorder, brief psychotic disorder is the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Stimulant intoxication :
Incorrect: Although stimulant intoxication must be considered in patients presenting with psychotic symptoms, this patient’s urinary drug screen is negative, which supports a diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the psychiatry clinic for evaluation of difficulty leaving the house for three weeks. The patient was recently in a car accident. Although he did not sustain any physical injuries, he reports poor sleep due to recurring nightmares and fears of experiencing another accident. He is unable to recall many details of the accident. These symptoms have affected his concentration at work, and he was recently reported to human resources for being irritable with a coworker. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The mental status exam reveals an anxious, diaphoretic male who appears his stated age and frequently scans the room. Which of the following factors in this patient’s history is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms—including avoidance behavior, memory deficits, nightmares, disrupted sleep, poor concentration, elevated blood pressure, diaphoresis, and hypervigilance—persisting for 3 weeks after a car accident are consistent with acute stress disorder, distinguishing it from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Symptoms related to trauma and stress disorders are organized into five categories: intrusive symptoms, negative mood symptoms, dissociative symptoms, avoidance behavior, and changes in arousal. To diagnose acute stress disorder, patients must exhibit at least 9 symptoms from these categories for more than 3 days but less than 30 days following the traumatic event.

In contrast, the criteria for PTSD require at least 1 intrusive symptom, 1 avoidance-related symptom, at least 2 negative mood or cognitive symptoms, and at least 2 arousal symptoms, all persisting for more than 30 days after the traumatic event. Adjustment disorder may be considered for patients with functional impairment related to a stressor who do not meet the full criteria for acute stress disorder or PTSD.  

Option Analysis

✅ Duration of symptoms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Avoidance behavior:
Incorrect: Avoidance behavior can occur with stressor-related and anxiety disorders. The duration of this patient’s symptoms is the factor most likely to confirm the diagnosis of acute stress disorder, rather than a nonspecific avoidance behavior.
❌ Elevated blood pressure:
Incorrect: An elevated blood pressure can be seen as a physiological response to anxiety, stress, or recent trauma. However, this patient’s symptoms are consistent with acute stress disorder, and it is the duration of symptoms that confirms the diagnosis.
❌ Poor concentration:
Incorrect: Poor concentration can occur in trauma-related disorders due to dissociative symptoms and physiological changes after trauma. However, because this symptom is common amongst the various trauma-related conditions, the duration of symptoms is the key factor in confirming acute stress disorder.
❌ Poor frustration tolerance:
Incorrect: Poor frustration tolerance can lead to irritability in individuals with trauma-related disorders. However, since this symptom is shared among these disorders, the duration of symptoms remains the most definitive factor for confirming the diagnosis of acute stress disorder.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman has come to the primary care office due to feeling depressed for the past two weeks. The patient feels her partner of six months is planning to leave her because he says he has been busy with work and occasionally staying late. The patient calls her partner multiple times a day for reassurance. While the patient has previously felt her partner was the greatest person, she now says he is a terrible person. The patient feels empty and has episodes of intense anger which have led to her being fired from her most recent job. She has a history of practicing non-suicidal self-injury during periods of severe emotional distress, and she has been performing this behavior recently. She does not have suicidal or homicidal thoughts. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations 17/minute, blood pressure is 123/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Mental status exam shows an anxious appearing patient with a limited range of affect. Which of the following additional features is most likely to be seen given the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Onset of symptoms and behaviors at 13-years-old

questions.solution:
This patient presents with depressed mood, efforts to avoid abandonment, non-suicidal self-injury, feelings of emptiness, intermittent intense anger, and splitting; these symptoms are consistent with borderline personality disorder (BPD). Impulsivity is an additional feature included in the DSM-5 TR diagnostic criteria for BPD.       

Borderline personality disorder is a personality disorder characterized by a pattern of unstable interpersonal relationships, distorted self-image, suicidality, and impulsivity. The impulsivity of patients with borderline personality disorder must be potentially self-damaging and occur in at least two areas of functioning. Examples of impulsive behavior may include driving recklessly, binge-eating, and overspending.        

To diagnose borderline personality disorder, the DSM-5 TR requires at least five symptoms to be present out of the nine symptoms linked to the disorder.     The DSM-5 TR includes efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment, patterns of unstable and intense relationships, identity disturbance, impulsivity resulting in self-harm, recurrent suicidality, chronic feelings of emptiness, intense anger, and transient mood-congruent paranoia and dissociation as symptoms that can be used to diagnose the condition. At least five of these symptoms must be present starting in early adulthood to diagnose the condition.        

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

✅ Impulsivity:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lack of empathy:
Incorrect: Lack of empathy is a core feature of narcissistic personality disorder and antisocial personality disorder, but not borderline personality disorder. This patient has features that are more consistent with borderline personality disorder.
❌ Onset of symptoms and behaviors at 13-years-old:
Incorrect: Conduct disorder requires features of the disorder to be present prior to the age of fifteen. However, this patient has borderline personality disorder, which does not have an age requirement. 
❌ Elevated self-esteem:
Incorrect: Patients with narcissistic personality disorder may have elevated self-esteem. However, this patient appears to have borderline personality disorder, which commonly manifests with poor self-esteem and struggles with self-image.  
❌ Avoidance of friendships:
Incorrect: Patients with schizoid personality disorder or avoidant personality disorder may avoid social interaction and friendships. However, this patient appears to have borderline personality disorder, and while she may have difficult or fractured friendships, she would not be avoidant of relationships and instead fears abandonment by others.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has come to the psychiatry office because of severe impulsivity and irritability. The patient has had these symptoms since she was a child. The patient experiences frequent impulses to steal. She does not experience guilt after she steals. She states she often manipulates the account of events when caught stealing to avoid interacting with police officers, which she has had to do on several occasions. The patient refers to her ability to convince others of false events as her magical gift. The patient’s irritability and frequently violent behavior has led to a legal separation from her partner. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations 16/minute, blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Mental status exam shows linear and logical thought processes, minimal psychomotor activity, flat affect, appropriate grooming and hygiene, and weather and setting-appropriate clothing. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s life-long stealing, lack of remorse, pattern of deceitfulness, and impulsivity are consistent with antisocial personality disorder. Patients with antisocial personality disorder display a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others. Symptoms must have occurred since age 15, and the patient must be at least 18 years old to receive the diagnosis.          

Antisocial personality disorder is a Cluster B personality disorder; Cluster B also includes borderline, histrionic, and narcissistic personality disorders. Antisocial personality disorder and narcissistic personality disorder share symptoms including a tendency to be superficial, exploitative of others, and a lack of empathy. However, patients with narcissistic personality disorder typically do not have impulsivity, aggression, and deceit, while these are common features of antisocial personality disorder. Antisocial personality disorder and histrionic personality disorder both include symptoms of impulsivity, superficial thoughts, and reckless behavior. However, patients with histrionic personality disorder do not typically engage in criminal behavior. While patients with both borderline personality disorder and antisocial personality disorder may manipulate others and situations, patients with antisocial personality disorder often manipulate to gain power or influence, while patients with borderline personality disorder often manipulate others to gain leverage in relationships.     

Option Analysis

❌ Conduct disorder:
Incorrect: Conduct disorder shares similar diagnostic criteria with antisocial personality disorder. However, conduct disorder is most commonly diagnosed in patients under 18 years old who do not meet criteria for antisocial personality disorder. 
✅ Antisocial personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Schizotypal personality disorder :
Incorrect: Magical thinking or odd beliefs are a feature of schizotypal personality disorder that can influence behavior. However, this patient’s attitude supportive of crime, her frequent interactions with the legal system, and lack of guilt or remorse are more consistent with antisocial personality disorder.  
❌ Histrionic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with histrionic personality disorder have a pervasive pattern of excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. This patient’s lack of emotional expression and lack of concern for the way others may perceive her behavior is more consistent with antisocial personality disorder. 
❌ Narcissistic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with narcissistic personality disorder present with a pervasive pattern of grandiosity and a need for admiration from others. This patient’s lack of concern with people’s perception of her behaviors and criminality are more consistent with antisocial personality disorder.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry clinic because of difficulty developing close friendships for the past several years. The patient wants friends and a romantic partner but is fearful of being rejected or embarrassed during social outings. She has declined multiple work promotions due to anxiety about being judged to be a poor supervisor. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Mental status exam shows an alert, cooperative adult who appears anxious and avoids eye contact. During the physical examination, the patient asks if the clinician is judging her negatively. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 29-year-old patient’s avoidance of social interactions due to fear of rejection or negative evaluation is characteristic of avoidant personality disorder. Patients with this disorder often want close social relationships but feel held back by feelings of inadequacy, hypersensitivity to criticism, and a chronically negative self-image. A diagnosis requires at least four of the symptoms listed in the table above.        

Unlike dependent personality disorder, which centers on clinging behavior and fear of separation, people with avoidant personality disorder want relationships but avoid them due to fear of rejection.        

The most difficult disorder to distinguish from avoidant personality disorder is social anxiety disorder. Both disorders feature anxiety about social interactions and fear of rejection. The key differences are in self-concept and pervasiveness. Individuals with avoidant personality disorder tend to have negative self-esteem and show avoidance across most social contexts. In social anxiety disorders, self-esteem is more stable (or even healthy), and anxiety often focuses on specific social scenarios, such as public speaking.    



Option Analysis

✅ Avoidant personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dependent personality disorder:
Incorrect: Dependent personality disorder involves an excessive need to be taken care of, a marked fear of perceived separation or abandonment, and difficulty making decisions without reassurance. However, this patient desires connection but avoids it due to fear of rejection, making avoidant personality disorder more likely.  
❌ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder :
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD) is characterized by preoccupation with order, control, and perfectionism at the expense of efficiency and flexibility. However, this patient’s avoidance is driven by social fears rather than rigidity or control-focused behaviors, making avoidant personality disorder the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by chronic, excessive anxiety about multiple topics (e.g., fitness, health, finances) and is not primarily focused on social fears or interpersonal relationships. This patient’s anxiety is rooted in fear of being judged socially, making avoidant personality disorder the most likely diagnosis.    
❌ Obsessive-compulsive disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder may frequently “check in” with others, such as this patient asking for reassurance that the clinician is not perceiving her negatively. However, this patient’s fears are social in nature and not driven by obsessions or compulsive rituals. Thus, avoidant personality disorder is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the primary care clinic for a 3-month history of a severe rash and skin picking. The patient feels as if bugs are crawling all over his body. There has been no recent exposure to scabies or bed bugs, and there is no past medical or psychiatric history. Documentation available on the electronic health record (EHR) shows multiple emergency department visits for concerns of parasite infestation. Collateral information obtained from the patient’s family reveals that the mother found needles in the patient’s room next to an unknown powder. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Dermatological exam shows multiple scattered excoriations covering the bilateral upper extremities in various stages of healing that appear self-inflicted. There is severe dental decay and tooth erosion. Mental status exam shows a thin adult with age-appropriate appearance and fair grooming and hygiene. Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) and complete blood count (CBC) are normal. The patient declines to complete a urinary drug screen. Which of the following is the most probable cause of the patient’s dermatological findings?
questions.solution:
This adult patient presents with rash, poor dentition, self-inflicted skin picking, delusions of parasitosis, and formication. Collateral information suggesting intravenous substance use raises concern for methamphetamine use disorder.         

While methamphetamine can be used through multiple routes of administration, patients who inject methamphetamine may display skin lesions reflective of injection sites. Additionally, formication, skin pricking, and delusions of parasitosis are classic signs of habitual methamphetamine use.       

When differentiating between chronic use of cocaine, methamphetamine, and MDMA, several key distinctions can be helpful. Methamphetamine use is more commonly associated with the above findings, in addition to severe dental decay and extreme weight loss. Cocaine use, however, is more frequently linked to nasal septal damage, cardiovascular complications, and seizures. Chronic MDMA use can cause enamel damage due to severe bruxism, memory impairment, mood swings (especially depression in the days following use), and, in rare cases, hyponatremia due to SIADH. While these characteristics can aid in the diagnosis, a urinary drug screen remains the most reliable method for identifying which substance may be contributing to the patient’s symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ Methamphetamine use disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cocaine use disorder:
Incorrect: Recent intranasal use of cocaine can damage nasal blood vessels, leading to epistaxis or hemoptysis, while chronic use may cause ischemic necrosis and perforation of the nasal septum. Cocaine can also be intravenous and may contribute to paranoia and hallucinations. However, it is not typically associated with delusions of parasitosis or formication. These symptoms are more characteristic of methamphetamine use disorder.  
❌ Marijuana use disorder:
Incorrect: Patients experiencing marijuana use disorder may present with conjunctival injection, anhedonia, increased appetite, and mood lability. However, scattered self-inflicted upper extremity lesions, delusions of parasitosis, and formication are more consistent with methamphetamine use disorder. 
❌ Inhalant use disorder :
Incorrect: Chronic inhalant use is associated with ataxia, poor cognitive functioning, and, rarely, dermal burns depending on the inhalant being used. These are unlikely to cause skin-picking lesions, delusions of parasitosis, and formication. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with methamphetamine use disorder. 
❌ Alcohol use disorder:
Incorrect: Patients experiencing chronic alcohol use disorder can present with neuropathy, hepatomegaly, gynecomastia, Dupuytren contracture, and spider angiomas if alcohol-induced cirrhosis is present. However, scattered self-inflicted upper extremity lesions from skin picking, delusions of parasitosis, and formication are more consistent with methamphetamine use disorder.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the neurology clinic with hand tremors for the past 9 months. The tremor began after the death of her father, which has been a significant source of emotional stress. Over the past several months, electromyography, brain and spinal MRI, and autoimmune testing have revealed no cause. There is no family history of essential tremor, Parkinson disease, or Huntington disease. Anxiety about the tremor led the patient to leave work and focus on finding its cause. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/74 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Neurological exam shows a bilateral hand tremor at rest that disappears during finger-to-nose testing. Mental status exam shows an anxious adult with appropriate grooming and hygiene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an idiopathic bilateral rest tremor that resolves during a distracting physical exam maneuver, with no identifiable cause despite a thorough diagnostic workup. This presentation is consistent with functional neurological symptom disorder.        

Functional neurological symptom disorder can be conceptualized as a subset of somatic symptom disorder defined by neurological symptoms. In both conditions, patients experience real, involuntary symptoms without identifiable structural or pathological causes. A helpful analogy for understanding somatic symptom disorder and functional neurological symptom disorder is that of a smart phone with a software malfunction. While the device appears structurally sound and intact, it can still fail to function properly. Similarly, in these disorders, while the body appears structurally normal, the patient experiences real and disruptive symptoms.       

When considering a diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder or functional neurological symptom disorder, physical exam maneuvers requiring coordination or concentration (e.g. finger-to-nose testing) may lead to spontaneous resolution of the symptom. However, it is important to recognize that despite this finding, patients are experiencing distressing symptoms involuntarily. This distinguishes somatic symptom disorder and functional neurological symptom disorder from malingering, in which patients voluntarily feign or exaggerate symptoms to obtain external incentives.   

Option Analysis

✅ Functional neurological symptom disorder :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Essential tremor:
Incorrect: Essential tremor manifests as tremors that worsen during movement or when maintaining posture. Finger-to-nose testing exacerbates action tremors, and holding the arms outstretched intensifies postural tremors. This patient’s tremor occurs primarily at rest, resolves with action, and shows no clear etiology or pathological findings, making functional neurological symptom disorder the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder:
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder involves significant worry about at least one physical symptom without a clear etiology. Because this patient’s presentation features a neurologic symptom, functional neurological symptom disorder is the most appropriate diagnosis. 
❌ Illness anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Illness anxiety disorder involves worry about having or developing a severe medical illness, typically without significant physical symptoms. Since this patient has a clear neurological sign, functional neurological symptom disorder is the more likely diagnosis.  
❌ Physiologic tremor:
Incorrect: A physiologic tremor is a normal, low-amplitude tremor that can present in times of emotional stress, anxiety, or after caffeine or stimulant use and is not pathologic. However, this patient’s tremor at rest, which disappears with voluntary movement, is more consistent with a functional neurological symptom.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the emergency department late in the evening due to severe depression for the past three weeks. Three hours ago, the patient had suicidal thoughts. The patient reports increased sleep, poor appetite, and significant psychomotor depression. Before these symptoms began, the patient experienced a 2-week period of elevated mood, reckless behavior, impulsivity, and racing thoughts, leading to job loss. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Mental status exam reveals an adult with a withdrawn affect and poorly maintained hygiene and grooming. Complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), and urinary drug screen are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Observation in the emergency department and reassess in the morning

questions.solution:
This 19-year-old patient’s symptoms, including depressed mood, disrupted sleep and appetite, intermittent suicidal ideation, psychomotor depression, and a recent period of increased energy, decreased need for sleep, impulsivity, and reckless behavior are consistent with acute bipolar depression. When evaluating a patient in the emergency department with bipolar disorder, it is essential to assess the risk of suicide. Given this patient’s recent suicidal thoughts in the context of severe depression, inpatient psychiatric hospitalization is recommended to allow for psychiatric stabilization prior to discharge.        

While psychiatric hospitalization criteria vary by state, an elevated risk of acute harm to self or others is a common criterion. Pharmacologic stabilization and close monitoring, such as a 1:1 sitter, may be necessary. In severe or treatment-resistant cases, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) can be considered. For patients presenting to the emergency department who are not at elevated risk of suicide, useful interventions may include suicide safety plans, outpatient referrals to psychiatry, or, in some instances, initiating psychiatric medication with scheduled follow-up with a primary care provider or psychiatrist.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

❌ Referral to outpatient psychiatry :
Incorrect: Referral to outpatient psychiatry may be a useful intervention for patients who do not meet inpatient criteria. However, this patient’s recent suicidal thoughts and severe depression suggest that inpatient hospitalization is more appropriate due to the high acute risk of harm to self if discharged.  
✅ Inpatient psychiatric admission :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Observation in the emergency department and reassess in the morning:
Incorrect: Allowing a patient to board in the emergency department overnight to allow for reassessment is a useful intervention, especially when patients present acutely intoxicated on a substance or when further information is needed before making a definitive clinical decision. However, this patient’s acute depressive symptoms and recent suicidal thoughts suggest inpatient hospitalization is the most appropriate intervention due to the high acute risk of harm to self. 
❌ Psychology consult for urgent debriefing :
Incorrect: Psychological debriefing is a technique previously used in trauma-informed care that focuses on providing brief psychotherapy shortly following a traumatic event. However, given this patient's acute depressive symptoms and recent suicidal thoughts, inpatient hospitalization is the most appropriate intervention, as the patient is at high acute risk of harm to self if discharged. 
❌ Suicide safety plan and discharge:
Incorrect: Suicide safety plans are tools that can help patients identify individuals, places, and resources to turn to when experiencing significant emotional distress. However, as this patient endorses recent suicidal thoughts and severe depressive symptoms, inpatient hospitalization is the most appropriate intervention due to the elevated risk of harm to self if discharged.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry clinic for a depressed mood over the past six months. There are no reports of sleep disruptions, changes in appetite, or anhedonia. Before the depressed mood began, the patient experienced heightened self-esteem and was easily distracted for six months but did not experience a decreased need for sleep or racing thoughts. The patient expresses frustration regarding these “mood swings” as they have disrupted her social life for the past five years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Mental status exam reveals a depressed adult who appears her stated age with appropriate grooming and hygiene. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), thyroid panel, and urinary drug screen, are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Bipolar II disorder with rapid cycling

questions.solution:
This adult patient presents with fluctuations in mood, depressed mood without meeting criteria for major depressive disorder, and periods of increased self-esteem and distractibility without meeting criteria for hypomania. This presentation aligns with cyclothymic disorder.        

To diagnose cyclothymic disorder, patients must have a history of subthreshold mood episodes for one to two years, depending on age. In adults, these fluctuations must persist for at least two years, with symptoms present for at least half the time and symptom-free intervals lasting no longer than two months. In children and adolescents, these fluctuations must persist for at least one year. As with bipolar I and II disorders, symptoms must be associated with functional impairment. Unlike bipolar disorder, cyclothymic disorder is less commonly associated with inpatient psychiatric hospitalizations due to the subthreshold nature of these episodes.        

The defining feature of cyclothymic disorder is chronic, fluctuating mood disturbances with numerous episodes of hypomanic and depressive symptoms. When differentiating bipolar spectrum disorders, the first step is to assess if the reported symptoms meet criteria for major depressive disorder, hypomania, or mania. Bipolar I or II disorder is diagnosed if the patient has ever experienced a manic or hypomanic episode, regardless of when it occurred.        

Substance-use disorders, particularly stimulant, alcohol, and benzodiazepine use, should be considered, as intoxication or withdrawal can mimic bipolar spectrum disorders. Assessing mood symptoms during periods of sustained sobriety can help clarify the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

❌ Bipolar I disorder:
Incorrect: Bipolar I disorder should be considered when patients present with frequent fluctuations in mood. However, this patient’s current symptoms of depression and history of elevated self-esteem do not meet criteria for major depressive disorder or a manic episode. Therefore, cyclothymic disorder is the most likely diagnosis.  
✅ Cyclothymic disorder :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bipolar II disorder:
Incorrect: Bipolar II disorder should be considered when patients present with frequent fluctuations in mood. However, this patient’s current symptoms of depression and history of inflated self-esteem do not meet criteria for major depressive disorder or a hypomanic episode. Therefore, cyclothymic disorder is the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Major depressive disorder :
Incorrect: Major depressive disorder requires at least five symptoms of depression occurring during the same two-week period. This patient has only two symptoms of depression. Additionally, the history of elevated self-esteem and distractibility does not fully meet the criteria of a hypomanic episode. Given her subthreshold mood changes over time, cyclothymic disorder is the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Bipolar II disorder with rapid cycling :
Incorrect: Bipolar II disorder with rapid cycling is characterized by four or more discrete periods of depression or hypomania over a 12-month period. As this patient’s symptoms of depression and past hypomanic symptoms do not meet DSM criteria for major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder, cyclothymic disorder is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department accompanied by police for evaluation of severe chest pain and agitation for 4 hours. The patient was found punching cereal boxes at a grocery store. The patient is unable to be redirected and threatens violence towards hospital staff. Temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg. Mental status exam shows a disheveled adult with agitated psychomotor activity. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and abdominal ultrasound are unable to be obtained due to patient refusal. Urinary drug screen is positive for phencyclidine. The patient receives intramuscular lorazepam after trying to attack a nurse. The patient’s breathing appears shallow and slowed shortly after receiving lorazepam. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of chest pain, physical agitation, disorganized behavior, and urine drug screen findings suggest phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. This is a potential medical emergency due to the risk of respiratory compromise and medical complications, such as rhabdomyolysis. Rapid assessment of airway, breathing, and circulation is critical in all cases of ingestion and intoxication.

After the ABCDE assessment, patients should undergo cardiac monitoring, receive supplemental oxygen if needed, and have intravenous access established. Benzodiazepines are the preferred chemical sedative for managing phencyclidine-induced agitation. If benzodiazepines are ineffective, antipsychotics (e.g., droperidol, haloperidol) can be used. External cooling measures may be necessary in a minority of cases where sedation does not alleviate hyperthermia. In severe cases, physical restraints may be required to ensure the safety of both the patient and the staff. Additional investigations, such as electrocardiogram, cardiac monitoring, and workups for rhabdomyolysis and associated metabolic derangements, should also be performed.     

Option Analysis

✅ Airway, breathing, and circulation assessment:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Echocardiogram :
Incorrect: Echocardiography may be useful in cases of chest pain to evaluate for cardiac causes, such as myocardial infarction or other structural heart conditions. However, in the context of phencyclidine toxicity, an echocardiogram is not necessary for immediate management. The primary concern in this case is respiratory depression following lorazepam administration, and rapid assessment of airway, breathing, and circulation is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Gastric lavage:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage is generally not recommended for the management of drug toxicity, especially in agitated patients. It is rarely used and should only be considered in specific situations such as life-threatening ingestions within one hour. The American Academy of Clinical Toxicology advises against its routine use due to the potential for complications, such as aspiration.
❌ Nasogastric suction:
Incorrect: Nasogastric suction is not routinely used in the management of phencyclidine intoxication. It is difficult to implement in agitated patients and carries risks such as electrolyte imbalances and aspiration. The primary concern in this case is respiratory depression following lorazepam administration, and rapid assessment of airway, breathing, and circulation is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Physical restraints:
Incorrect: Physical restraints should be reserved as a last-resort intervention when a patient’s agitation poses an immediate risk to their safety or the safety of others. However, the primary concern in this case is respiratory depression following lorazepam administration, and rapid assessment of airway, breathing, and circulation is the most appropriate next step.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for a 30-minute history of sedation and unresponsiveness. The patient was found by his significant other on the floor of their apartment next to an empty bottle of lorazepam. According to the fiancé, the patient had recently lost a job and may have increased the dose of lorazepam without informing a physician, due to worsening anxiety. Past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder and generalized epilepsy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows slowed breathing. Mental status exam reveals a heavily sedated individual who does not respond to verbal stimuli. Naloxone is administered without improvement in sedation. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score is 10. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 50-year-old patient with significant sedation and unresponsiveness after being found unconscious near a bottle of lorazepam, suggesting benzodiazepine overdose. The mainstay of treatment is supportive care, focusing on airway, breathing, and circulation. Most cases of isolated benzodiazepine intoxication or overdose improve with time as the drug is metabolized, and no specific antidote is required.

Flumazenil, a competitive antagonist of the benzodiazepine receptor, may reverse sedation but is generally avoided in patients with seizure risk, including those with epilepsy or chronic benzodiazepine use. Its use may precipitate withdrawal seizures and render benzodiazepines ineffective if seizures occur.

Gastrointestinal decontamination measures such as activated charcoal are not routinely recommended due to limited benefit and risk of aspiration in sedated patients. Gastric lavage is also no longer routinely used given the elevated risk of complications and lack of clear benefits.

Given the overlapping clinical features of opioid and benzodiazepine toxicity, naloxone is often administered when the diagnosis is unclear. In this case, lack of response to naloxone supports benzodiazepine overdose. Finally, when managing an acute overdose, empiric interventions should not be delayed by diagnostic testing when clinical suspicion is high. Early supportive measures, such as respiratory support (e.g., supplemental oxygen, intubation) and intravenous fluids remain the cornerstone of care.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.

Option Analysis

✅ Supportive treatment:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Flumazenil:
Incorrect: Flumazenil is a competitive benzodiazepine antagonist that can reverse sedation in a benzodiazepine overdose. However, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of chronic benzodiazepine use or seizure disorders, as it can precipitate withdrawal seizures. Given the available answers, the mainline treatment of benzodiazepine toxicity is supportive treatment.  
❌ Gastric lavage:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage is rarely indicated and carries an elevated risk of aspiration and other complications, especially in patients with decreased consciousness. The American Association of Poison Control Centers now recommends against its use in nearly all cases of poisoning. Given the available answers, the mainline treatment of benzodiazepine toxicity is supportive treatment.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal is a highly absorbent powder that can absorb chemicals within minutes of contact due to its high surface area, which can prevent gastrointestinal absorption and toxicity in certain cases of poisoning or overdose. Activated charcoal is not routinely used in isolated benzodiazepine ingestion due to minimal supportive evidence and the risk of aspiration. The mainline treatment of benzodiazepine toxicity is supportive treatment.
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis can reduce the toxicity of certain medications or toxins but does not enhance benzodiazepine elimination. There are currently no established methods to accelerate benzodiazepine metabolism or clearance. The mainline treatment of benzodiazepine toxicity is supportive treatment.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic with a 6-month history of fatigue and anhedonia. There is a past psychiatric history of panic disorder managed with clonazepam, but no other medical, substance use, or surgical history. Clonazepam has been taken at least daily since graduating from college due to anxiety while job searching. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 55/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a regular rhythm, but the patient is more bradycardic compared to prior exams. Neurological exam reveals an ataxic gait. Mental status exam shows a drowsy-appearing adult with subtle deficits in short-term memory and concentration. Complete blood count (CBC) and comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) are normal. Urinary drug screen is pending. Which of the following types of additional history is most appropriate to obtain now?
questions.solution:
This 24-year-old patient presents with subacute gait disturbance, slowed mentation, and drowsiness in the context of likely increasing clonazepam use. This presentation raises concern for unintentional benzodiazepine intoxication. During periods of significant life stress, it is essential to review medication use and adherence, as stressful events may lead to escalated use of as-needed medications like clonazepam.

Although benzodiazepines carry a high potential for misuse and diversion, acute intoxication may also result from misunderstandings about proper use rather than intentional misuse. Common findings in benzodiazepine or barbiturate intoxication include slurred speech, ataxia, nystagmus, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and altered mental status ranging from drowsiness to coma. Vital sign abnormalities such as bradycardia, hypotension, and hypoventilation may occur, particularly with barbiturate overdose or in the setting of polypharmacy.  

One useful strategy to evaluate a patient’s comprehension of a new prescription is the teach-back method, in which the patient explains how they intend to use the medication. This approach helps identify and prevent miscommunication about dosing or frequency.   

Option Analysis

✅ Details of current medication use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recreational substance use:
Incorrect: When evaluating new onset of fatigue and anhedonia, reviewing recent recreational substance use is a useful portion of a complete medical history. However, in this case, the presence of bradycardia, drowsiness, cognitive slowing, and gait disturbance in the context of known chronic clonazepam use makes it more urgent to clarify the extent and pattern of medication use.
❌ Family medical history:
Incorrect: Family medical history can provide useful information about predisposition to certain conditions. However, it is unlikely to explain the subacute cognitive and motor findings observed in this individual. The current priority is evaluating the potential contribution of prescribed medications.
❌ History of similar symptoms:
Incorrect: While a history of similar episodes can be informative, it is less relevant in this context than clarifying this patient’s current medication use, given the neurological signs and known benzodiazepine exposure.
❌ Nutritional habits:
Incorrect: Nutritional habit changes are a possible cause of fatigue and anhedonia, but they do not typically account for bradycardia, drowsiness, or gait abnormalities. Medication effects must be evaluated first in this case.

questions.text: A 34-year-old nonbinary adult presents to the emergency department because of confusion, short-term memory difficulty, and trouble walking steadily that began approximately 8 hours ago. The patient’s partner found the patient wandering around the apartment and noted multiple empty blister packs on the kitchen counter. Medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder treated with fluoxetine and alprazolam. The partner reports the patient ran out of alprazolam two weeks ago and has since been using phenobarbital purchased online to manage anxiety symptoms. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 14 min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mmHg. Neurologic examination reveals disorientation to time, impaired short-term recall, slurred speech, and an unsteady gait. Blood alcohol is undetectable. Urinary drug screen is pending. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This 34-year-old patient’s confusion, slurred speech, short-term memory impairment, and ataxia in the context of known alprazolam and phenobarbital use are consistent with benzodiazepine or barbiturate intoxication. Since this patient ran out of alprazolam and does have access to phenobarbital, barbiturate intoxication is the most likely diagnosis.

To confirm a diagnosis of barbiturate or benzodiazepine intoxication, the DSM-5 requires evidence of recent use, mood or behavioral changes attributable to the substance, and at least one symptom of intoxication such as incoordination, dysarthria, nystagmus, impaired memory, or gait disturbance.

Barbiturate or benzodiazepine use disorder is a separate diagnosis and requires at least two behavioral or functional criteria within a 12-month period, such as tolerance, withdrawal, cravings, using more than intended, or continuing use despite harm. Withdrawal is also distinct and requires reduced or stopped use after prolonged intake along with symptoms such as anxiety, dysphoria, tremor, insomnia, muscle pain, or hallucinations.

Option Analysis

✅ Barbiturate intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Barbiturate use disorder:
Incorrect: Barbiturate use disorder refers to a chronic pattern of compulsive barbiturate use despite harmful consequences. It would not explain this patient’s acute symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and short-term memory impairment, which are consistent with barbiturate intoxication.
❌ Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) overdose:
Incorrect: Overdose of SSRIs such as fluoxetine typically results in nausea, tremor, drowsiness, and potentially serotoninergic symptoms. This patient lacks features of serotonin syndrome (e.g., hyperreflexia, clonus, autonomic instability) and instead presents with neurologic findings more consistent with benzodiazepine or barbiturate intoxication.
❌ Benzodiazepine withdrawal:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepine withdrawal generally causes anxiety, insomnia, tremors, and in severe cases, seizures. Ataxia and memory impairment are not characteristic features of withdrawal but are more consistent with intoxication.
❌ Alcohol intoxication:
Incorrect: Although alcohol intoxication can cause ataxia and cognitive changes, this patient’s blood alcohol level is undetectable. The clinical picture and known use of phenobarbital strongly suggest barbiturate intoxication as the cause of symptoms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the psychiatry office due to paranoia for the past 25 days. The patient feels that other students are undercover and working with their professor to lower his grades. Due to this concern, the patient no longer socializes with classmates. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg. Mental status exam shows a young adult who appears his stated age with minimal mood reactivity and a restricted range of affect. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Urine drug screen is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with persecutory delusions for the past 25 days meets the criteria for brief psychotic disorder, a condition within the schizophrenia spectrum. It involves symptoms of psychosis that last for more than one day but less than a month. Diagnosis requires at least one of the following symptoms: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or catatonic behavior.         

If this patient’s symptoms persist for more than one month, delusional disorder, persecutory type, can be diagnosed. Both brief psychotic disorder and delusional disorder require just one symptom for the diagnosis, while schizophreniform disorder and schizophrenia require at least two symptoms.        

Schizophreniform disorder should be considered when symptoms last more than one month but less than six months. When symptoms persist for more than six months, a diagnosis of schizophrenia may be more appropriate. Unlike other schizophrenia spectrum disorders, schizoaffective disorder requires mood symptoms that meet criteria for a depressive or manic episode.   

Option Analysis

✅ Brief psychotic disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Schizophreniform disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with schizophreniform disorder can present with persecutory delusions and other psychotic symptoms. However, the diagnosis requires symptoms to persist for more than one month but less than six months. This patient's symptoms have lasted only 25 days, which does not meet the duration criteria. 
❌ Schizophrenia :
Incorrect: Patients with schizophrenia can exhibit persecutory delusions and other psychotic symptoms. However, the diagnosis of schizophrenia requires symptoms to persist for at least six months, including at least one month of active-phase symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech). This patient's symptoms have lasted only 25 days, which does not meet the duration criteria. 
❌ Delusional disorder :
Incorrect: Delusional disorder, persecutory type, is a reasonable diagnosis to consider. However, delusional disorder requires symptoms to persist for at least one month without other psychotic features such as hallucinations or disorganized behavior. Since this patient’s symptoms have been present for only 25 days, brief psychotic disorder is the more appropriate diagnosis based on the duration criteria. 
❌ Schizoaffective disorder :
Incorrect: Schizoaffective disorder can include persecutory delusions, but it requires the presence of a mood episode (depressive or manic) occurring concurrently with psychotic symptoms. This patient does not exhibit any mood symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider because of a depressed mood that has persisted for several months. She also cites reduced sleep, frequent nighttime awakenings, reduced appetite, and a 2 kg (4.4 lb) weight loss. Her partner notes that she has been irritable and no longer enjoys going camping or playing with her dogs. Her maternal uncle died by suicide at the age of 30, and her mother has a history of generalized anxiety disorder. Past medical history is notable for hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and her blood pressure is 155/77 mmHg. Which of the following additional findings in this patient would make duloxetine the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Sensory loss in the bilateral lower limbs

questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD), such as depressed mood, loss of appetite, sleep disturbances, loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities, and increased irritability. Duloxetine, a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), is useful in treating MDD and concurrent diabetic neuropathy.   

Diabetic neuropathy can cause sensory loss, motor weakness, and a burning sensation in the extremities. Duloxetine can exert analgesic properties by increasing norepinephrine and serotonin activity, which prevents excess pain stimuli from reaching the brain. As a result, duloxetine is useful in treating conditions associated with chronic pain, such as diabetic neuropathy and fibromyalgia.  

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

❌ Sexual dysfunction :
Incorrect: Bupropion inhibits norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake and is used as an atypical antidepressant. The medication has a favorable sexual side effect profile and can be used as an alternative to SSRIs and SNRIs. In contrast, SSRIs and SNRIs are likely to cause sexual dysfunction and decreased libido.  
❌ Desire to quit smoking :
Incorrect: Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that can treat the major depressive disorder and promote smoking cessation. In contrast, duloxetine does not have the same effect on smoking cessation.   
❌ History of bulimia nervosa :
Incorrect: Mirtazapine is an α2-antagonist that promotes weight gain. As a result, it is preferred in treating major depressive disorder in patients with a history of anorexia or bulimia nervosa.   
✅ Sensory loss in the bilateral lower limbs :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of insomnia :
Incorrect: Trazodone has sedative properties since it is an antagonist at 5-HT2 and H1 receptors. It can be used in patients with major depressive disorder and concurrent insomnia. In contrast, duloxetine and other SNRIs would likely exacerbate the patient’s insomnia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the psychiatrist for a follow-up visit. The patient has been suffering from major depressive disorder for the past 2 years. The patient has been on numerous different therapies, including citalopram and fluoxetine, with varying degrees of success. In addition, she has been experiencing decreased libido and progressive weight gain. The patient asks for a different therapy that does not have these side effects. Which one of the following treatments is ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient comes to the physician with side effects of antidepressant therapy including weight gain and decreased libido. These are common symptoms of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). To minimize these side effects, the patient should be switched to bupropion.  

Bupropion is an inhibitor of norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake used to help treat depression and assist in smoking cessation. Bupropion has also been shown to be effective in the prophylactic treatment of seasonal affective disorder. Since it does not directly act upon serotonin receptors, bupropion does not cause weight gain. Moreover, the medication is not associated with sexual side effects.   

However, bupropion has been shown to decrease the seizure threshold and is contraindicated in patients at increased risk of seizures (e.g., history of epilepsy, anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa).   

Option Analysis

❌ Trazodone:
Incorrect: Trazodone is an antidepressant that primarily inhibits serotonin reuptake. It can cause sedation and sexual dysfunction. As a result, it would not be an ideal medication for this patient.  
❌ Mirtazapine:
Incorrect: Mirtazapine is a serotonin and histamine receptor antagonist. The medication can increase appetite and cause weight gain. As a result, it would not be an ideal medication for this patient.  
✅ Bupropion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Venlafaxine:
Incorrect: Venlafaxine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that can be used in the treatment of depression. SNRIs are associated with sexual dysfunction and should be avoided in this patient.  
❌ Phenelzine:
Incorrect: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor that is rarely used due to its toxicity and drug-drug interactions. MAOIs can cause sexual dysfunction and weight gain and should be avoided in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with long standing major depressive disorder and insomnia presents to the emergency room with a chief complaint of right upper abdominal pain and dark urine. The patient has taken several antidepressants over the years, including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and atypical antidepressants. The patient cannot remember the most recent medication that he is taking. Upon further evaluation, the patient also endorses dry mouth, nausea and constipation. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus as well as slight jaundice of the tongue and skin. Which antidepressant is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Trazodone and nefazodone are both antidepressants used in the treatment of major depressive disorder. The medications work by acting as a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor. In addition, the medication has antihistamine properties. These characteristics make trazodone and nefazodone effective in treating both depression and insomnia.    

The two drugs share many of the same side effects inducing dry mouth, nausea, and constipation. Both medications can potentially cause priapism, though the incidence is lower for nefazodone. Moreover, nefazodone has been shown to cause hepatotoxicity in approximately 1 in 250,000 patients. Although the mechanism of hepatotoxicity is still unclear, postmarket analysis shows that some patients develop life threatening hepatotoxicity within 2-6 weeks of taking the drug. For this reason, it is advised that nefazodone be discontinued in patients who have elevated transaminase levels.   

Option Analysis

❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine can cause side effects including dry mouth, sexual dysfunction, inability to sleep, and headaches. In contrast, this patient’s presentation of right upper abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice are more suggestive of hepatotoxicity. Fluoxetine does not typically cause hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Bupropion:
Incorrect: Side effects of bupropion include seizures, headache, and insomnia. This patient’s symptoms of right upper abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice are more suggestive of hepatotoxicity caused by a different medication.   
❌ Escitalopram:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of right upper abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice are more suggestive of hepatotoxicity. In contrast, escitalopram and other selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors do not typically cause this side effect.  
❌ Trazodone:
Incorrect: Trazodone has many of the same side effects as nefazodone. However, this patient’s symptoms of right upper abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice are more suggestive of hepatotoxicity, which is commonly associated with nefazodone therapy.   
✅ Nefazodone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A physician scientist is performing postmarket monitoring for a pharmaceutical company. She has been assigned to compare the efficacy of two drugs: vortioxetine and vilazodone.
