The two drugs are antidepressants with nearly identical mechanisms of action. Both of these medications act as inhibitors of serotonin reuptake, as well as either partially or fully agonizing the 5-HT1A serotonin receptor. Which of the following is true regarding the efficacy of vortioxetine as compared to vilazodone at the 5-HT1A receptor?

choices.text: At the same dose, vortioxetine is less efficacious.
At the same dose, vilazodone will always have a submaximal effect.
As a partial agonist, vortioxetine has partial inhibitory effects at the 5-HT1A receptor.
Vilazodone is equally effective as vortioxetine.
As a full agonist, vortioxetine binds to and inhibits the 5-HT1A receptor.

questions.solution:
Vortioxetine and vilazodone are both serotonin reuptake inhibitors. The two also impact the 5-HT1A serotonin receptors. Vortioxetine is a full agonist of the 5-HT1A receptor. By contrast, vilazodone is a partial agonist of the 5-HT1A receptor. The combination of serotonin reuptake inhibition as well as agonism of 5-HT1A receptors make these two drugs powerful serotonergic potentiators.    

As a full agonist at the 5-HT1A receptor, vortioxetine has a higher efficacy. It produces a full response while occupying a relatively low proportion of receptors. In contrast, vilazodone, as a partial agonist of 5-HT1A receptors, will produce a submaximal effect even when occupying all available receptors.

 

Option Analysis

❌ At the same dose, vortioxetine is less efficacious. :
Incorrect: As a full 5-HT1A receptor agonist, vortioxetine is able to exert a greater effect at the same dose.   
✅ At the same dose, vilazodone will always have a submaximal effect.:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ As a partial agonist, vortioxetine has partial inhibitory effects at the 5-HT1A receptor.  :
Incorrect: As opposed to vilazodone, vortioxetine is a full agonist at the 5-HT1A receptor.  
❌ Vilazodone is equally effective as vortioxetine.:
Incorrect: As a partial agonist at the 5-HT1A receptor, vilazodone will have a lesser effect than vilazodone at the 5-HT1A receptor.  
❌ As a full agonist, vortioxetine binds to and inhibits the 5-HT1A receptor.:
Incorrect: Agonists are agents that bind to receptors and propagate their endogenous mechanism of action.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the clinic because he has heard voices for the past nine months. According to his parents, the patient has been acting strangely over the past year. He dropped out of school and broke contact with his friends. He has been increasingly obsessed with government conspiracies and believes the government has placed trackers in his body. The patient is diagnosed with schizophrenia and prescribed an antipsychotic medication. He presents to the clinic again three months later after having developed involuntary and bothersome movements of the lips and tongue and writhing movements of the extremities. Which of the following medications has the highest risk of causing this side effect?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of tardive dyskinesia, which are more likely to occur in patients taking first-generation antipsychotics such as thioridazine.

Antipsychotics are used to treat schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. First-generation antipsychotics, also known as typical antipsychotics, block dopamine D2 receptors in the brain. These include haloperidol, pimozide, trifluoperazine, fluphenazine, thioridazine, and chlorpromazine. They are associated with several side effects, including hyperprolactinemia, metabolic syndrome, QT prolongation, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., acute dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia). Typical antipsychotics often end in the suffix “-azine”.

Second-generation antipsychotics, also known as atypical antipsychotics, work via inhibition of dopamine D2 receptors in the mesolimbic pathway and inhibition of serotonin 5-HT2A receptors in the mesocortical pathway. Standard atypical antipsychotics include clozapine, olanzapine, quetiapine, paliperidone, risperidone, lurasidone, ziprasidone, and aripiprazole. Per naming convention, atypical antipsychotics usually end in the suffixes “-apine” or “-idone”. Notably, atypical antipsychotics have a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms than the typical antipsychotics.

Option Analysis

❌ Risperidone:
Incorrect: Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic with a lower risk of tardive dyskinesia when compared to first-generation antipsychotics. Risperidone is associated with symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, such as amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and gynecomastia. Atypical antipsychotics usually end in “-apine” or “-idone”.  
✅ Thioridazine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clozapine:
Incorrect: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic with a lower risk of tardive dyskinesia when compared to first-generation antipsychotics. Side effects associated with clozapine include metabolic syndrome, agranulocytosis, and increased seizure risk.  
❌ Aripiprazole:
Incorrect: Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic with a lower risk of tardive dyskinesia when compared to first-generation antipsychotics. Atypical antipsychotics usually end in “-apine” or “-idone”.  
❌ Paliperidone:
Incorrect: Paliperidone is an atypical antipsychotic with a lower risk of tardive dyskinesia. Atypical antipsychotics usually end in “-apine” or “-idone”.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by concerned family members. Over the past few weeks, the patient thinks she can “control the weather” and is worried that the government is after her. In addition, the patient has been ignoring her hygiene and withdrawing from her friends. Her past medical history is notable for bipolar disorder, for which she is taking lithium. She is started on aripiprazole, given the onset of psychotic symptoms. What is the proposed mechanism of action for this new medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is started on aripiprazole, an atypical antipsychotic that works by acting as a partial agonist at D2 receptors.

Atypical antipsychotics have two main mechanisms of action: inhibition of dopamine D2 receptors in the mesolimbic pathway and inhibition of serotonin 5-HT2A receptors in the mesocortical pathway.  These medications treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, anxiety disorders, depression, mania, and Tourette syndrome.

Aripiprazole is unique among the atypical antipsychotics as it not only inhibits 5-HT2A receptors but also acts as a partial agonist of D2 and 5-HT1 receptors. Partial agonism of D2 receptors may explain why aripiprazole helps treat the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia and its lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms, hyperprolactinemia, and QT-interval prolongation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Partial agonism of D2 receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Partial agonism of 5-HT2A receptors:
Incorrect: Like other atypical antipsychotics, aripiprazole is a 5-HT2A receptor antagonist. These receptors are found throughout the central and peripheral nervous systems. They are found in high concentrations on platelets as well. Partial agonists of the 5-HT2A receptor include ergolines, tryptamines, and phenethylamines. Full agonists include the classic psychedelic drugs like LSD and psilocin.  
❌ Inhibition of 5-HT1 receptors:
Incorrect: Aripiprazole is thought to partially stimulate 5-HT1 receptors.  
❌ Inhibition of 5-HT reuptake:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) act as antidepressants. SSRIs include fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, sertraline, and escitalopram. Significant side effects include serotonin syndrome, gastrointestinal distress, SIADH, and sexual dysfunction.  
❌ Inhibition of norepinephrine uptake:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) act as antidepressants. SNRIs include venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, levomilnacipran, and milnacipran. Significant side effects include hypertension, sedation, and nausea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic for increasing breast size over the last five months. The patient has noticed that his breasts are getting larger and tender to touch. He is very bothered by this change and wants to know what can be done to reverse it. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia and hypertension. Current medications include risperidone, hydrochlorothiazide, and lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam is significant for enlarged breasts bilaterally. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities would likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a patient with schizophrenia who developed gynecomastia due to hyperprolactinemia secondary to risperidone use. This side effect occurs since the atypical antipsychotics block dopamine receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway. Amongst the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone is most likely to cause hyperprolactinemia.

The tuberoinfundibular pathway refers to a population of dopamine neurons in the arcuate nucleus (also known as the "infundibular nucleus") in the tuberal region of the hypothalamus that projects to the pituitary median eminence (the "infundibular region"). It is one of the four major dopamine pathways in the brain. Dopamine released at this site regulates prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland.

Blockade of dopamine receptors leads to an increase in prolactin, which inhibits the release of GnRH, LH, and FSH. Patients will subsequently develop hypogonadism. Women may present with hirsutism, acne, oligomenorrhea, or amenorrhea. Men can develop gynecomastia. Both men and women can experience infertility, sexual dysfunction, galactorrhea, and decreased bone mineral density.

Ideally, if a patient develops hyperprolactinemia, the atypical antipsychotic should be discontinued. However, if this is not possible, then either 1) the dose may be decreased, 2) the patient can be switched to an alternative atypical antipsychotic, or 3) a full or partial dopamine agonist may be added to the regimen.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased prolactin levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased GnRH levels:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, likely secondary to risperidone use. Risperidone increases prolactin release, which in turn suppresses GnRH secretion.  
❌ Decreased aromatase activity:
Incorrect: Aromatase is an enzyme that facilitates the peripheral conversion of testosterone to estrogen. The activity of this enzyme is not affected by risperidone or the other medications this patient is taking.  
❌ Normal LH and FSH levels:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, likely secondary to risperidone use. Risperidone increases prolactin release. Given that prolactin suppresses GnRH release, the levels of LH and FSH are decreased in patients with hyperprolactinemia. These changes contribute to hypogonadism in both men and women.  
❌ Normal testosterone levels:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, likely secondary to risperidone use. Risperidone increases prolactin release. Given that prolactin suppresses GnRH, the levels of LH and FSH are decreased, and thus, testosterone levels are also reduced.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police after he was found unresponsive outside a convenience store. The patient lives in a shelter home and was recently discharged from a hospital after being treated for polysubstance use. The patient is not currently taking any medications. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 5/min, and blood pressure is 120/87 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination shows pinpoint pupils that do not respond to light. The patient is somnolent and only withdraws his limbs to pain. Fingerstick blood glucose is 85 mg/dL. A bag valve mask ventilates the patient. Supplemental oxygen and intravenous fluids are started. Administration of which of the following medications is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of polysubstance use is presenting with hypoventilation, hypothermia, and pinpoint pupils. These findings are concerning for opioid intoxication. The next best step in management is to administer naloxone.

Naloxone is a μ-receptor antagonist administered through multiple routes, including oral, intravenous, intranasal, intramuscular, sublingual, and subcutaneous. It has a rapid onset and short duration of action of 1 to 2 hours. When given intravenously, it can reverse the effects of an opioid overdose within minutes and potentially save the patient’s life. In addition, when women in labor need to take opioid analgesics, opioid molecules can pass through the placenta and cause respiratory depression in the fetus. Administering naloxone can also reverse this complication.

When naloxone is administered to individuals with a history of chronic opioid dependence, they may develop symptoms of opioid withdrawal, including anxiety, tremors, body aches, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, sweating, and increased heart rate and blood pressure.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Naloxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deferoxamine:
Incorrect: Deferoxamine is a chelating agent used to treat iron poisoning, which can present acutely with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. An unresponsive patient with a depressed respiratory rate, pinpoint pupils, and a history of polysubstance use is more suggestive of opioid intoxication.  
❌ N-acetylcysteine:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen intoxication. Affected patients present with nonspecific symptoms of nausea, vomiting, malaise, and signs of liver damage (e.g., jaundice, coagulopathy). An unresponsive patient with a depressed respiratory rate, pinpoint pupils, and a history of polysubstance use is more suggestive of opioid intoxication.  
❌ Methylene blue:
Incorrect: Methylene blue is the antidote for methemoglobinemia, which most commonly occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents (e.g., dapsone, nitrate, topical/local anesthetics). An unresponsive patient with a depressed respiratory rate, pinpoint pupils, and a history of polysubstance use is more suggestive of opioid intoxication.  
❌ Hydroxocobalamin:
Incorrect: Hydroxocobalamin can be used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It avidly binds cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted via the urine. Cyanide toxicity should be considered in patients with a history of smoke inhalation, carbonaceous material in the oropharynx, neurologic dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, or elevated serum lactate concentration. In contrast, an unresponsive patient with a depressed respiratory rate, pinpoint pupils, and a history of polysubstance use suggests opioid intoxication.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for heroin withdrawal. The patient states, “I need to get clean, doctor. I will do anything to make sure I do not use it again.” Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 173/95 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic male with diffuse piloerection, rhinorrhea, and mydriasis. In addition to providing symptomatic relief, which of the following is the most appropriate medication to prevent relapse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of heroin withdrawal, including rhinorrhea, piloerection, and sympathetic hyperactivity. In addition, the patient seeks relapse prevention, which can be achieved by administering buprenorphine.    

Although rarely life-threatening, the symptoms of acute opiate withdrawal are uncomfortable to the patient and should be treated accordingly. Symptoms include mydriasis, piloerection, diaphoresis, rhinorrhea, yawning, sneezing, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea). Patients may also experience sympathetic hyperactivity (e.g., hypertension, tachycardia).  

Several medications can be used to treat the symptoms of acute opiate withdrawal, including antiemetics, intravenous fluids, and benzodiazepines.    

In addition, clonidine has been shown to improve the symptoms of opiate withdrawal. The medication is a sympathoplegic that interacts with ɑ2-receptors to decrease sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system. As a result, clonidine can mitigate the adrenergic effects of acute opiate withdrawal.  

Several medications also exist to prevent relapse in patients with a history of opiate use disorder. These include methadone, buprenorphine, and naltrexone. Buprenorphine acts as a partial agonist at the μ-opiate receptor. Naltrexone is a long-acting oral opioid antagonist. Methadone is a full μ-opiate receptor agonist with a long duration of action. It relieves cravings, mitigates withdrawal symptoms, and helps treat heroin addiction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Buprenorphine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is a full agonist at opiate receptors. Administration of this medication may treat this patient’s withdrawal symptoms. However, morphine is not typically used for relapse prevention.   
❌ Mirtazapine:
Incorrect: Medications such as mirtazapine function as ɑ2-antagonists, thereby increasing the release of norepinephrine and serotonin. This medication is not used to treat the symptoms of opiate withdrawal or prevent relapse.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a μ-opiate receptor antagonist and can be used to reverse symptoms of opiate overdose rapidly. Administration of this medication will likely exacerbate this patient’s symptoms. Moreover, naloxone is not used to prevent relapse in patients with a history of opiate use disorder.  
❌ Clonidine:
Incorrect: Clonidine is a centrally acting ɑ2-agonist and is often used to treat the uncomfortable adrenergic symptoms associated with opiate withdrawal. It does not help prevent relapse in patients with a history of opioid use disorder.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with two days of diaphoresis, insomnia, and irritability. She recently stopped taking her high-dose phenelzine, which she had been taking for five years with adequate results. She expresses a desire to pursue a “natural approach” to managing the depression with St John’s wort. Past medical history is significant for borderline personality disorder, conversion disorder, and severe refractory depression. She is not currently taking any medications. Vital signs are unremarkable. Physical examination is remarkable for diaphoretic skin and mild agitation. Which of the following should be done next to help manage this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing drug discontinuation symptoms due to abruptly stopping her MAOI. Antidepressants should be tapered off and not abruptly stopped, especially MAOI. MAOI discontinuation syndrome generally presents with anxiety, insomnia, and irritability. Many patients also experience chills, diaphoresis, and nausea. In some cases, patients can develop delirium or psychotic features. If a patient wishes to discontinue their MAOI, it should be slowly tapered off over 4 weeks.  

In patients with MAOI discontinuation syndrome, the appropriate treatment is to start therapy on the same MAOI and dose they were previously on. There is no indication to initiate a different MAOI during this time period if the previous MAOI worked well. In addition, herbs and supplements should not be used to treat symptoms of abrupt discontinuation.

Option Analysis

❌ Provide cognitive behavioral therapy:
Incorrect: While this would likely be of benefit to this patient in the long term, it is more important that her short-term symptoms are addressed by resuming phenelzine.
❌ Refer to psychiatry:
Incorrect: While this patient would likely benefit from seeing a psychiatrist, it is appropriate to treat her symptoms now by resuming phenelzine.
✅ Resume phenelzine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Start isocarboxazid:
Incorrect: There is no reason to start a different monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) to help with drug discontinuation symptoms.
❌ Start St. John’s wort:
Incorrect: St. John’s wort has reportedly mild MAOI activity and is not an appropriate substitute for a high-dose MAOI medication.

questions.text: A 26- year-old woman comes to the clinic for follow-up of major depression. The patient was diagnosed 2 years ago when she presented with a persistent depressed mood, low energy, poor appetite, and diminished concentration at work. She has been on fluoxetine, escitalopram, mirtazapine, and amitriptyline with persistence of her symptoms and poor treatment response. Over the last 2 weeks, she has avoided spending time with her family and friends and prefers to be alone in her room. There is a family history of bipolar disorder in her mother and social anxiety disorder in her sister. The patient does not consume alcohol, smoke or use recreational drugs. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. BMI is 20 kg/m2. She is cooperative, alert, and responds to questions. She demonstrates insight regarding her illness. Which of the following serves as the mechanism of action of the most appropriate medication for treatment of her symptoms?

choices.text: Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors with anticholinergic effects

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of treatment-resistant depression and has been administered multiple antidepressant medication classes including SSRIs, TCAs, and atypical antidepressants. Treatment-resistant depression refers to unipolar depressive episodes that do not respond adequately to sequential treatments with different classes of antidepressants. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors are not considered first line agents for unipolar depression due to their unfavorable side effect profile; however, have been found to be effective in treatment-resistant depression. Other indications for selective MAO inhibitors use include the treatment of atypical depression (leaden paralysis, mood reactivity, increased sleep, and appetite).  

Monoamine oxidases are enzymes involved in the deamination (catabolism) of biogenic amines including serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine. Examples of MAOI include tranylcypromine, phenelzine, isocarboxazid, and selegiline. Other serotonergic antidepressants must be discontinued for 2 weeks prior to initiating an MAOI to prevent adverse effects such as hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome. Dietary restrictions limit the use of MAOI particularly tyramine-containing foods such as cured meat, cheese, and wines should be avoided to prevent a hypertensive crisis. Adverse effects include hypotension, dry mouth, gastrointestinal disturbances, urinary hesitancy, and myoclonic jerks.  



Option Analysis

❌ Presynaptic serotonin reuptake inhibitor:
Incorrect: SSRIs like fluoxetine are presynaptic serotonin inhibitors that inhibit the reuptake of serotonin.  This patient has been administered fluoxetine in the past with a poor response to treatment
✅ Monoamine oxidase inhibitor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor:
Incorrect: Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine. It is the treatment of choice for depression when smoking cessation and a favorable sexual side effect is desired. This patient has previously received an atypical antidepressant (Mirtazapine) with an inadequate response.
❌ 5HT1A receptor agonist :
Incorrect: Buspirone has a high affinity for 5HTA1 receptors and is indicated in the treatment of generalized anxiety due to its favorable side effect profile. It has not been found to be effective in the management of treatment-resistant depression.
❌ Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors with anticholinergic effects :
Incorrect: Tricyclic antidepressants are antagonists to cholinergic receptors and inhibit the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Their use is limited due to their cardiac, neurological, and anticholinergic effects. This patient has received amitriptyline in the past with a poor response to therapy.

questions.text: A 69- year-old woman is brought to the emergency room with her partner after losing consciousness at church. The partner states that there was no seizure-like activity, nausea, and vomiting. She regained consciousness 2 minutes after the syncopal episode. Her medical history includes atypical depression and GERD. Her current medication is a transdermal antidepressant that selectively inhibits MAOb receptors at low doses and is a nonselective MAO inhibitor at higher doses. Family history is noncontributory. She does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. She smokes 2-3 packs of cigarettes daily. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg while standing and 110/70 mm of Hg while lying down. BMI is 20 kg/m2. She is awake, alert, and responds to commands and external stimuli. Pupils are equal and reactive. She moves all her extremities, and +2 reflexes are present throughout. The antidepressant used in this patient is also the agent of choice in the presence of which of the following additional findings on evaluation?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with a syncopal episode and orthostatic hypotension. She has a history of receiving a selective MAO inhibitor that may be responsible for her symptoms. Monoamine oxidases are enzymes involved in the deamination (catabolism) of biogenic amines including serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine. Examples of MAOI include tranylcypromine, phenelzine, isocarboxazid, and selegiline.    

The enzyme MAO exists as MOAb and MAOa. MAOb metabolizes dopamine and MAOa metabolizes both serotonin and norepinephrine. Selegiline is a selective MAOb inhibitor at low doses and a non-selective MAO inhibitor at higher doses. Low-dose selegiline does not exert antidepressant effects and is a pharmacological agent used in the treatment of parkinson’s disease to increase cerebral levels of the monoamine dopamine.  At higher doses, selegiline functions as a nonselective MAO inhibitor and is included in the management of treatment-resistant depression and atypical depression.    

Other serotonergic antidepressants must be discontinued for 2 weeks prior to initiating an MAOI to prevent adverse effects such as a hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome. Dietary restrictions limit the use of MAOI particularly tyramine-containing foods such as cured meat, cheese, and wines should be avoided to prevent a hypertensive crisis. Due to enhanced dopamine levels as a result of MAOb inhibition, selegiline can cause hypotension (which can put the elderly on treatment at an increased risk for falls and fractures), nausea, vomiting, dry mouth, gastrointestinal disturbances, urinary hesitancy, and myoclonic jerks.  



Option Analysis

✅ Resting tremors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of bulimia nervosa :
Incorrect: Mirtazapine is an alpha2 antagonist that is used as an atypical antidepressant. It is preferred in the treatment of MDD in patients with a history of anorexia or bulimia, as it promotes weight gain. A history of bulimia nervosa is not an indication to initiate selegiline.
❌ Desire to stop smoking:
Incorrect: Atypical antidepressants like bupropion and varenicline are preferred for smoking cessation in patients with major depressive disorder. Selective MAOb inhibitors are not used as first-line agents for smoking cessation and major depressive disorder due to their unfavorable side effect profile.
❌ Chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain:
Incorrect: Fibromyalgia is a somatic symptom disorder that presents as chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain with point tenderness on examination. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that has been found to be effective in the management of fibromyalgia.
❌ Neuropathic pain in the extremities:
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy in diabetics can present with neuropathic pain. Among the first line agents used to treat neuropathic pain includes SNRIS such as venlafaxine and duloxetine.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found wandering in the park shouting and laughing to himself. The patient has been hearing the voices of his deceased mother and a world-famous singer. The patient has been hospitalized twice in the past, during which his symptoms improved after receiving haloperidol. The patient stopped the medication after discharge due to its side effects. After the patient's condition improves, he is discharged with a prescription for chlorpromazine, for which possible side effects are discussed. When compared to haloperidol, chlorpromazine is more likely to cause which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Typical antipsychotics are classified according to their potency. Low-potency antipsychotics (e.g., chlorpromazine) require higher doses to achieve the same effect as high-potency ones (e.g., haloperidol). Moreover, the two classes of medications have varying side effect profiles.

Low potency antipsychotics have stronger sedating (due to histamine H1 receptor blockade), anticholinergic (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention), and α1-receptor blockade (orthostatic hypotension) side effects.

In contrast, high-potency antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing neuroleptic malignant syndrome and extrapyramidal symptoms. Extrapyramidal symptoms include acute dystonia (involuntary muscle spasm), akathisia (inability to remain still), pseudo-parkinsonism (tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia), and tardive dyskinesia (repeated lip-smacking, choreiform movements of the extremities).  

Option Analysis

❌ Involuntary neck muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic. In contrast, high-potency antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as dystonia.  
❌ Inability to sit still:
Incorrect: Chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic. In contrast, high-potency antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as akathisia.  
✅ Sedation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bradykinesia:
Incorrect: High-potency antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as pseudo-parkinsonism, which manifests with bradykinesia, tremors, and rigidity. In contrast, chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic.  
❌ Repeated lip smacking:
Incorrect: High-potency antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as tardive dyskinesia, which manifests with involuntary repetitive such as lip smacking and writhing of the extremities. In contrast, chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by his parents because of unresponsiveness for the past 2 hours. The patient visited the emergency department 6 weeks ago following a suicide attempt. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia and major depressive disorder. Current medications include haloperidol and sertraline. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. Physical examination reveals an obtunded patient with increased resistance to passive motion in all extremities. Laboratory testing reveals a serum creatinine level of 3.5 mg/dL and creatine kinase of 76,000 U/L. The patient is started on intravenous fluids, lorazepam, and placed under a cooling blanket. Despite these initial measures, the symptoms persist. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diffuse muscle rigidity, fever, and elevated creatinine kinase in the setting of haloperidol use. These findings are suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). The best initial step in management is to administer dantrolene.

NMS is a life-threatening neurological emergency that typically occurs days to weeks after starting the offending medication. It is associated with the use of typical antipsychotic drugs (e.g., haloperidol, fluphenazine) that block brain dopamine receptors (especially D2 receptors), antiemetic drugs (e.g., metoclopramide), and sometimes atypical antipsychotics.

NMS is characterized by confusion, coma, agitation, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, and hyperthermia. These symptoms are almost identical to serotonin syndrome caused by antidepressants like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. However, serotonin syndrome typically causes hyperreflexia and dilated pupils, whereas neuroleptic malignant syndrome is more commonly associated with hyporeflexia and normal pupils.

If the condition progresses, NMS can cause rhabdomyolysis and elevated creatinine kinase levels. Treatment of NMS consists of removing the offending agent and supportive care. In severe cases, dantrolene can be administered. Dantrolene depresses the excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle by acting as a ryanodine receptor antagonist and decreasing free intracellular calcium.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Cyproheptadine:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine is a serotonin antagonist that blocks 5-HT2 receptors and is used as an antidote in patients with serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome causes hyperreflexia and dilated pupils, rather than the hyporeflexia and normal pupils seen in this patient.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is the agent of choice in patients with hypertensive urgency and emergency. Although this patient has a markedly elevated blood pressure, the additional findings of diffuse muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and elevated creatine kinase are more suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.  
❌ Valbenazine:
Incorrect: Valbenazine can be used in the management of patients with tardive dyskinesia (TD). Although TD can occur as a complication of typical antipsychotics, this patient’s presentation of diffuse muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and elevated creatine kinase are more suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.  
✅ Dantrolene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Benztropine:
Incorrect: Benztropine is used in the management of extrapyramidal side effects associated with typical antipsychotics. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office with her spouse for a follow-up appointment. The patient was diagnosed with schizophrenia 2 months ago due to a history of paranoid delusions, disorganized thoughts, and auditory hallucinations. She was started on haloperidol. The patient feels relieved that the voices in her head have gone away since starting haloperidol therapy. However, her spouse has noticed that she has been smiling less, and her movements have slowed. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is calm and cooperative but has a sad effect. The patient exhibits a pill-rolling tremor in the bilateral hands and does not swing her arms when she walks. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with tremors, decreased arm swing, and bradykinesia in the setting of antipsychotic use. These findings are suggestive of antipsychotic-induced parkinsonism.

Patients can also present with cogwheel rigidity, a mask-like face, and a shuffling gait. The symptoms can begin a few days to months after initiation of antipsychotic treatment. Of note, first-generation (typical) antipsychotics are more likely to cause parkinsonism than second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics.

Symptoms can be reversed by decreasing the antipsychotic dose as well as by concomitantly administering an antimuscarinic agent (e.g. benztropine) or dopaminergic agonist (e.g. amantadine). Patients can also be switched to an antipsychotic with less potential to cause extrapyramidal symptoms, such as a low-potency first-generation antipsychotic or second-generation antipsychotic.  

Option Analysis

❌ Switch from haloperidol to risperidone:
Incorrect: Risperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA). SGAs are less likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms when compared to first-generation antipsychotics. However, among the SGAs, risperidone is most likely to cause antipsychotic-induced parkinsonism. Therefore, switching to risperidone is not the best step.  
✅ Start benztropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discontinue haloperidol immediately:
Incorrect: This patient is demonstrating symptomatic improvement while on haloperidol. Adding an anticholinergic medication, rather than discontinuing haloperidol, is the next best step in management.  
❌ Start propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta-blocker and can be used in the management of akathisia, which is characterized by an inner feeling of restlessness and inability to sit still. However, propranolol is not effective in treating drug-induced parkinsonism.  
❌ Switch from haloperidol to valbenazine:
Incorrect: Valbenazine acts as a vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2) inhibitor and is used to treat tardive dyskinesia (TD). TD is characterized by constant, involuntary, rhythmic movements. The condition often involves the perioral muscles and can cause patients to repeatedly smack or purse their lips. Instead, this patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of drug-induced parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the psychiatrist for follow-up regarding recurrent panic attacks. Ever since his mother died one month ago, the patient has been experiencing episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, and an impending sense of doom whenever she is mentioned during discussions. He states, “I just need something to help take the edge off.” Past medical history is notable for anxiety, alcohol use disorder, and cocaine use. The patient was recently discharged from a rehabilitation facility for alcohol use disorder. He has not had any recent alcohol or recreational drug use. Physical examination and vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following medications has the highest potential for misuse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a strong history of polysubstance use and recent discharge from a rehabilitation facility presents with panic disorder. Of the medications listed, alprazolam has the highest misuse potential given its relatively short half-life and onset of action. As a result, it should only be used with extreme caution in this patient.  

Benzodiazepines are a class of medications used in the treatment of anxiety, panic disorder, and alcohol withdrawal. Care should be given when prescribing these medications to patients with a history of substance abuse, as the pharmacokinetics of certain benzodiazepines carry high addictive potential. For example, the medications alprazolam, triazolam, oxazepam, and midazolam have relatively short half-lives and a fast onset of action. Ultimately, these characteristics result in a higher addictive potential since the medication’s euphoric effects are achieved faster and do not last as long.    

Conversely, benzodiazepines that tend to have a lower potential for addiction are those with a slower onset of action and longer duration of action. Benzodiazepines that fit these criteria include chlordiazepoxide, lorazepam, clonazepam, and diazepam. These medications are safer for use in individuals with a history of addiction or substance misuse.   

Option Analysis

✅ Alprazolam :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lorazepam :
Incorrect: Lorazepam has an intermediate onset of action and a longer duration of action than other benzodiazepines. Thus, it has a lower addictive potential. 
❌ Clonazepam:
Incorrect: Clonazepam has a slow onset and long duration of action, making this medication less prone to abuse. 
❌ Chlordiazepoxide :
Incorrect: Chlordiazepoxide is a long-acting benzodiazepine and therefore carries a smaller abuse potential. 
❌ Buspirone:
Incorrect: Buspirone is a serotonin agonist used in the treatment of anxiety and can be safely prescribed to this patient.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of lack of sexual desire and difficulty achieving an erection for the past month. Before developing his symptoms, he had an active and satisfactory sexual relationship with his partner. He has no history of cardiac disease, unexpected weight loss, visual changes, or neuropathy symptoms. He reports a significant improvement in his mood and fatigue after initiating pharmacologic therapy for major depressive disorder six weeks ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and paroxetine. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in the patient’s father. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a normal body hair distribution, no gynecomastia, equal peripheral pulses bilaterally, an intact bulbocavernosus reflex, and normal testicular size. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's sexual dysfunction? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Hemoglobin A1c     5.9 %    
 Creatinine     0.8 mg/dL    
 Total testosterone      455 ng/dL    
 Prolactin     10 ng/mL    
 HDL     45 mg/dL    
 LDL     65 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s onset of erectile dysfunction (ED) and loss of libido following the initiation of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), in the absence of vascular, neurologic, hormonal, and psychogenic abnormality, make medication the most likely cause of ED.

SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, sertraline, paroxetine, and citalopram) allosterically inhibit the serotonin transporter (SERT) by binding at a site other than that of serotonin and increases its levels in the synaptic cleft. SSRIs are indicated for treating a major depressive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, OCD, and generalized anxiety disorder. SSRIs are considered one of the safest antidepressant medications due to their favorable side effect profile, but significant side effects can occur.

Sexual dysfunction including decreased libido, orgasmic difficulties or anorgasmia, penile anesthesia, and erectile dysfunction (impotence) are common adverse effects of SSRIs in males and females. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can be managed by switching to a non-SSRI antidepressant, such as bupropion or mirtazapine, which carry fewer sexual side effects. Other side effects of SSRIs include anxiety, insomnia, GI distress, and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormones (SIADH). Additional side effects include suicidal ideation, especially in individuals under 25, and serotonin syndrome.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Medication side effect :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vascular disease :
Incorrect: This patient’s normal vascular examination (e.g., absence of bruit and normal pulses) and well-controlled diabetes mellitus make a vascular abnormality an unlikely cause of erectile dysfunction in this patient. 
❌ Psychogenic :
Incorrect: Psychogenic erectile dysfunction typically presents with a sudden onset and is situational (e.g., with a specific partner and normal erection during masturbation). A psychological stressor usually precedes the onset of psychogenic ED. The onset of ED with decreased libido following the initiation of paroxetine supports the diagnosis of medication-induced ED. 
❌ Neurologic :
Incorrect: This patient’s normal neurologic examination (e.g., normal sensation, motor function, and intact bulbocavernosus reflex) makes this an unlikely cause of ED in this patient. 
❌ Hormonal  :
Incorrect: Normal testosterone and prolactin levels in the absence of gynecomastia make a hormonal imbalance an unlikely etiology of this patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to intermittent severe lethargy. He began experiencing severe agitation, tremors, and feelings of anxiety and irritability approximately 6 hours ago. During that time he had several episodes of non-bloody non-bilious vomiting. The patient has a 24-pack-year smoking history and, for the past 30 years, drinks half a liter of liquor a day. Temperature is 37.8 ºC (100.0 ºF), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 162/99, and SpO2 is 97% on room air. On physical examination, scleral icterus and mild ascites are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient suffers long-term from severe alcohol use disorder and is experiencing lethargy mixed with severe agitation, tremors, and feelings of anxiety and irritability suggestive of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. In order to relieve his withdrawal symptoms and prevent possible seizures, the best drug of choice is a benzodiazepine. Benzodiazepines bind between the alpha and gamma subunits of the GABA receptor, increasing the frequency of channel opening. Alcohol works in a similar fashion on the GABA receptor, producing mild sedative effects. Within the benzodiazepine drug class, lorazepam, oxazepam, and temazepam are not metabolized by the cytochrome p450 system in the liver. This makes them preferred agents for patients with cirrhosis, liver dysfunction, or the elderly. Lorazepam is the most commonly used agent among these.        
Barbiturates by contrast interact with the alpha and beta subunits of the GABA receptor, increasing the duration of GABA receptor opening. This makes barbiturates more likely to produce severe adverse side effects such as lethargy, coma, and even death. They are usually reserved for cases where benzodiazepine therapy is ineffective.   

Option Analysis

❌ Midazolam :
Incorrect: In this patient presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, a benzodiazepine is the best first-line treatment. While midazolam is a benzodiazepine, it is extensively metabolized in the liver and thus is not recommended for patients with hepatic dysfunction or in the elderly, as its duration of action can be unpredictable. 
❌ Chlordiazepoxide :
Incorrect: In this patient presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, a benzodiazepine is the best first-line treatment. While chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine, it is extensively metabolized in the liver and is erratically absorbed intramuscularly. It is not recommended as initial therapy for patients with hepatic dysfunction or in the elderly. For patients requiring hospitalization, a fast-onset IV benzodiazepine is more appropriate. 
❌ Phenobarbital :
Incorrect: While phenobarbital (a barbiturate) has a similar sedative effect as benzodiazepines, it is not the best first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Barbiturates have a very narrow therapeutic index, making them more prone to adverse side effects such as lethargy, coma, and even death. They should only be used in patients resistant to benzodiazepine therapy. 
✅ Lorazepam :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thiopental :
Incorrect: Thiopental is a barbiturate which was historically used for induction of general anesthesia. It is no longer used in the United States of America.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after he was found confused and distressed in a local park, prompting bystanders to call for help. The patient is unable to provide a medical history. A pharmacy dispense report available on the electronic health record shows a recent prescription for pimozide was issued three weeks prior to presentation. Pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/minute, blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient opens his eyes to stimuli and mumbles incoherently. His clothing is soiled with urine. The airway is stable. Musculoskeletal examination is notable for diffuse muscle rigidity. Laboratory results are shown below. Brain imaging, lumbar puncture, and initial infection evaluations are negative. A toxicology screen is negative for recreational substances. Which of the following additional findings would support a diagnosis of a medication side effect?  

 Laboratory Value      Result     
 Glucose, CSF      40 mg/dL     
 Creatine Kinase      8271 U/L     
 Bilirubin, Total      0.9 mg/dL     
 Bilirubin, Direct      0.2 mg/dL     
 Creatinine       4.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The findings in This patient of muscle rigidity, altered mental status, autonomic dysfunction, elevated CPK, shortly after starting the antipsychotic medication pimozide are concerning for neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). NMS is a rare but life-threatening syndrome that is caused by excessive dopamine antagonism. It occurs most often in patients taking first-generation or “typical” antipsychotics, like pimozide. Fever to 101°F (38.3°C) would be another finding consistent with NMS.

NMS and serotonin syndrome can have overlapping features. However, patients with NMS do not typically develop hyperreflexia and gastrointestinal symptoms, like nausea and vomiting that are seen with serotonin syndrome. Other diagnoses that can be in the differential include Acute intoxication from stimulants like cocaine and MDMA which can cause similar symptoms. As seen in NMS. However, these agents do not cause the severe rigidity that is pathognomonic for NMS. Akathisia is a movement disorder that can also be caused by antipsychotic medications; however, patients typically have uncomfortable restlessness and do not typically present with altered mental status. Tardive dyskinesia is another movement disorder caused by excessive dopamine antagonism; however, it does not cause autonomic instability, severe rigidity, or acute symptoms requiring treatment in the emergency department.    

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: This patient taking pimozide and presenting with muscle rigidity, altered mental status and urinary incontinence most likely has NMS. Hyperreflexia is a common finding in serotonin syndrome, which can present similarly to neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). However, patients with NMS present with normal or diminished reflexes.     
❌ Dry, warm skin:
Incorrect: Dry, warm skin is common in patients experiencing anticholinergic toxicity. This patient is experiencing neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which leads to diaphoresis.  
❌ Bladder distention:
Incorrect: Bladder distension from urinary retention can occur in patients taking anticholinergic medications or in those experiencing anticholinergic toxicity. This patient is experiencing neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which typically presents with urinary incontinence due to activation of the sympathetic nervous system. 
✅ Temperature of 101°F (38.3°C):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Leukopenia:
Incorrect: Leukopenia may occur in patients taking medications like clozapine, which can cause this as a side effect. However, patients with neuroleptic malignant syndrome commonly present with leukocytosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the primary care clinic because three months of difficulty falling asleep, poor appetite, fatigue, and inability to enjoy any of the activities that were previously pleasurable. He has not previously had episodes of depression and has never experienced mania or hypomania. He reports no recent stressors or life changes. The patient feels overwhelming guilt on a daily basis about how he has let down his family with his job choices, which makes it difficult for him to work efficiently. He has been consistently handing in assignments late. He no longer plays pickleball, which had previously been his favorite pastime. He has no significant medical history and takes no prescribed medications or recreational substances. He does not have suicidal ideations, homicidal ideations, delusions, or hallucinations. Temperature is 37°C (98.6 F°), pulse is 70/min, respirations 16/minute, blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears poorly groomed, with stains on his clothing and disheveled hair. He displays limited eye contact and speaks quietly. Mental status exam is significant for a narrow range of affect and increased latency response. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing a lack of pleasure or enjoyment, feelings of guilt, difficulty sleeping, fatigue, decreased appetite, and psychomotor slowing along with occupational impairment; this presentation meets criteria for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD).        

Major depressive disorder is diagnosed in patients experiencing at least 5 of the following 9 symptoms for at least two weeks: depressed mood, changes in Sleep, lack of Interest, feelings of Guilt, decreased Energy, poor Concentration, changes in Appetite, Psychomotor slowing or agitation, and Suicidality. The mnemonic “SIGECAPS” can be used to help remember the symptoms in addition to depressed mood.        

Major depressive disorder is distinguished from bipolar disorder when patients have a history of mania or hypomania. Bipolar I disorder is diagnosed when the patient meets the criteria for a current or past manic episode. A bipolar II diagnosis applies when there are current or past hypomanic episodes. Cyclothymia is a milder form of bipolar disorder that involves frequent mood swings but with less severe symptoms, lasting over two years in adults or over one year in children and adolescents.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.     

Option Analysis

✅ Major depressive disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Adjustment disorder:
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder can be diagnosed in patients who develop depressive symptoms after a significant stressor or change in life circumstances. While this patient has depressive symptoms, he has not had recent stressors or life changes.  
❌ Bipolar disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with bipolar disorder experience significant depressive episodes but also experience manic or hypomanic episodes. This patient has only had depressive symptoms without manic or hypomanic episodes; therefore, a diagnosis of bipolar would not apply.  
❌ Cyclothymic disorder:
Incorrect: Cyclothymia is characterized by the combination of episodes of hypomanic or manic symptoms that do not meet criteria for hypomanic or manic episodes and episodes of depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for major depressive disorder that have lasted for at least two years. This patient’s timeline of symptoms is too short for a diagnosis of cyclothymia, and his depressive symptoms meet criteria for major depressive disorder.  
❌ Persistent depressive disorder:
Incorrect: Persistent depressive disorder is characterized by depressive symptoms for at least two years. This patient has no history of previous depressive episodes or symptoms; therefore, persistent depressive disorder cannot be diagnosed.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for a 6-month history of severe anxiety. She has no significant past medical, surgical, or psychiatric history. Her anxiety occurs suddenly without anything specific setting it off, and she experiences sweating, chest tightness, palpitations, and numbness around her lips. She often must leave the room she is in during an anxiety episode. She continues to work and participate in social gatherings though she has refused some invitations from friends lately because of worry about future attacks. For the past two months, she has been fearful and worried that these episodes could start while working or during class. She does not exhibit other fears or intrusive thoughts. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Physical exam reveals an anxious-appearing woman who appears her stated age and uses a soft tone of voice. She is reactive and attenuates to noises outside the examination room. Neurological examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 19-year-old patient with recurrent, sudden-onset, unprovoked severe anxiety, heart palpitations, sweating, and perioral numbness is experiencing panic attacks. She has also had over one month of fear and worry about future episodes and has started changing her behavior to avoid future attacks. The most likely diagnosis is panic disorder.        

Panic disorder is characterized by excessive fear or worry of future panic attacks. It can be thought of as anxiety about future anxiety. To diagnose panic disorder, patients must have recurrent panic attacks in addition to at least one month of pervasive fear of future panic attacks or making behavioral changes to avoid future panic attacks.        

Patients with panic disorder may also experience agoraphobia. Agoraphobia is fear of situations where escape is difficult or help is not readily available. Patients with agoraphobia may avoid public transportation, crowded social events, open spaces like parking lots, or enclosed spaces like a movie theater. Some patients also experience fear of being outside of their own homes, which may result in patients having difficulty leaving their homes. Patients with panic disorder who also exhibit symptoms of agoraphobia must have these symptoms for six months to receive a diagnosis of panic disorder with agoraphobia.    

Option Analysis

❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with generalized anxiety disorder have excessive worry or anxiety about routine situations, like finances, relationships, or day-to-day tasks. This patient is experiencing panic attacks and worries about future panic attacks, making panic disorder the more appropriate diagnosis. 
✅ Panic disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Social anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with social anxiety disorder have anxiety relating to social situations that may result in being judged or embarrassed by others. This patient has anxiety related to having future panic attacks, and her anxiety is focused on social interactions, making panic disorder the most appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Obsessive-compulsive disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder have intrusive thoughts that improve with ritualistic behavior. This patient does not have obsessive thoughts or ritualistic behavior. However, she does have panic attacks and anxiety about future panic attacks, suggesting panic disorder as the most appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Specific phobia:
Incorrect: Patients with specific phobias have anxiety and excessive fear of a specific situation, object, or concept. This patient’s anxiety is centered on the fear of future panic attacks, making panic disorder the most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of 1 hour of chest pain, nausea, and numbness around his lips. This is his third emergency department visit in over six months for similar episodes. He states that these episodes are not brought on by any specific situations. He has no significant past medical history and no family history of coronary artery disease. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Mental status exam reveals an anxious and diaphoretic man with a soft tone of voice. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Neurologic exam is normal. Electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia but does not show ischemia. Troponins are negative. Which of the following additional symptoms would help confirm a diagnosis of panic disorder in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 20-year-old patient presenting with chest pain, nausea, perioral numbness, diaphoresis, and tachycardia is experiencing symptoms of a panic attack. To diagnose panic disorder, patients must have excessive worry or fear of future panic attacks for at least one month or maladaptive changes in behavior to avoid having panic attacks for one month. While panic disorder is defined by fear of panic attacks, it is important to remember that panic attacks can occur in generalized anxiety disorder and other psychiatric conditions.       

When evaluating a patient with a concern for an anxiety disorder, it is important to characterize the subject, timing, and context of the anxiety, in addition to any associated behaviors. Compared to panic disorder, patients with generalized anxiety disorder experience excessive worry or fear of routine situations like finances, work, and relationships. Agoraphobia is excessive fear of public transportation, open spaces, enclosed spaces, lines, or being outside of the home alone. Patients with panic disorder can often have agoraphobia as well. Patients with specific phobias have excessive fear of specific situations, like heights or exposure to blood. Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) experience repetitive disturbing thoughts and feel compelled to perform repetitive actions, like handwashing, to help get rid of the thoughts.    

Option Analysis

✅ Fear of future episodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fear of public transportation :
Incorrect: Marked fear of public transportation is a symptom of agoraphobia and is not diagnostic criteria for panic disorder, though patients can be diagnosed with panic disorder with agoraphobia.
❌ Intrusive thoughts:
Incorrect: Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder have intrusive thoughts that improve with ritualistic behavior. Intrusive thoughts are not part of the diagnostic criteria for panic disorder. 
❌ Fear of heights:
Incorrect: Fear of heights is a common phobia in patients with specific phobia. Phobias are not included in the diagnostic criteria of panic disorder. 
❌ Repetitive hand washing:
Incorrect: Repetitive handwashing is a common compulsion in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Compulsions are not included in the diagnostic criteria of panic disorder.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry office to establish care. She recently moved to the area and needs a new psychiatrist. She cannot recall her previous diagnoses but reports being on a stable dose of aripiprazole, which was started 8 years ago due to auditory hallucinations involving the FBI and delusions of thought insertion. Although she is mostly asymptomatic, her residual symptoms impair her ability to work. She does not have a history of mood episodes consistent with mania, hypomania, or depression. Her temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. On mental status exam, she appears her stated age with a flat affect and demonstrates linear, logical thought processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 28-year-old patient’s history of auditory hallucinations, delusions of thought insertion, flat affect, absence of manic or depressive episodes, and occupational impairment for years is most suggestive of schizophrenia.        

Schizophrenia is defined by the presence of two or more psychotic symptoms for at least six months. The duration helps differentiate it from similar disorders, such as schizophreniform disorder, where symptoms last between one and six months, and brief psychotic disorder, in which symptoms are present for less than one month. These symptoms must cause significant impairments in the patient’s ability to work, maintain interpersonal relationships, or perform self-care. Symptoms of psychosis include delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized or catatonic behavior, and negative symptoms. Negative symptoms can be thought of as “something taken away,” such as a reduction in affect, social engagement, or motivation.        

Because mood disorders with psychotic features and schizoaffective disorder may also present similarly, it is important to assess patients for active or past symptoms suggestive of mania, hypomania, or depression before confirming a diagnosis of schizophrenia.    

Option Analysis

❌ Delusional disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with delusional disorder may exhibit paranoid delusions. However, this patient’s flat affect, auditory hallucinations, and delusions of thought insertion are more consistent with schizophrenia.  
✅ Schizophrenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Schizophreniform disorder:
Incorrect: Schizophreniform disorder presents with similar symptoms to schizophrenia but is defined by a duration of symptoms between one and six months. Since this patient has had at least two symptoms of psychosis for over six months, schizophrenia is the most appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Brief psychotic disorder :
Incorrect: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last less than one month. Given that this patient's symptoms have persisted for more than six months, schizophrenia is the most appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Paranoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although paranoid personality disorder may involve paranoia, the presence of true psychotic symptoms (e.g., auditory hallucinations, delusions of thought insertion) strongly favors a primary psychotic disorder such as schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a severe panic attack lasting three hours. He describes recurrent panic attacks occurring three times a week following a car accident eight months ago, which resulted in the amputation of his right arm. These panic attacks are often triggered by intrusive thoughts or nightmares about losing his left arm. He also experiences persistent anxiety, avoids social interactions, and feels "not real" at times. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. The musculoskeletal exam reveals normal strength and sensation in the left upper extremity. Dermatological exam shows well-healing scar tissue overlying a recent amputation on his right upper extremity. On mental status examination, he is anxious and diaphoretic with a limited range of facial expressions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with anxious distress

questions.solution:
This patient’s frequent panic attacks, social avoidance, nightmares, emotional blunting, and intrusive thoughts of losing his remaining limb over the past eight months raise concern for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The vignette states that the patient underwent an amputation following a motor vehicle accident, and his current symptoms are rooted in that traumatic experience.

The timing of symptom onset is essential when considering a diagnosis of PTSD. If a patient has a history of psychiatric symptoms before experiencing a traumatic event, the trauma may have exacerbated an existing condition. However, a trauma-related disorder is more likely if a patient with no prior psychiatric history develops symptoms following the trauma. It is important to recognize that patients can, and often do, meet criteria for both a trauma-related disorder and another psychiatric disorder.

Another factor to consider when diagnosing PTSD is the overlap of trauma-related symptoms with those of other psychiatric conditions. Patients with trauma-related disorders experience symptoms specifically tied to the traumatic event. In contrast, conditions such as obsessive-compulsive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and borderline personality disorder lack a single, identifiable focal point and involve more generalized symptom patterns.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obsessive-compulsive disorder:
Incorrect: Although both post-traumatic stress disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder can involve repetitive, distressing thoughts, this patient’s intrusive thoughts are tied to his traumatic experience. Additionally, he lacks the compulsions or ritualistic behaviors characteristic of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
✅ Post-traumatic stress disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Major depressive disorder with anxious distress:
Incorrect: While major depressive disorder with anxious distress can share diagnostic features such as a negative mood and cognitive symptoms, this patient’s symptoms began after a clear traumatic event, making post-traumatic stress disorder more likely.
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive worry about multiple life domains, whereas post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms are specifically tied to a traumatic event. In this case, the patient’s concerns about losing a limb, his avoidance of social interactions, and his dissociative experiences are all directly linked to his recent traumatic experience, making post-traumatic stress disorder the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: Both borderline personality disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder can induce dissociative states and social avoidance, with dissociation often occurring as a coping mechanism for overwhelming negative emotions. However, this patient’s symptoms began after a clear traumatic event, which strongly supports a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man has come to the primary care office to establish care. He moved to the area 3 months ago. He has no significant medical, surgical, or psychiatric history. When asked about his recent move, the patient states he is a world-renowned video game streamer. The patient requests that multiple specific laboratory studies be ordered to ensure “he is healthy enough to bless his followers with content.” The patient shares that he is envious of a rival streamer, and he wants to be healthy so he can obtain more followers than her. The patient states that he has always done well in school and at work and that he has “always been on a steady path to success.” He asks if he can record the visit to inspire his viewers to stay healthy. When informed that recording the visit is against office policy, the patient appears confused and replies, “Who else besides me would they listen to about their health?” Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg.  On examination, the patient appears to be his stated age, is in formal attire with carefully maintained grooming and hygiene. Mood, affect, and pattern of speech are appropriate. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s grandiose perception of his success and influence, preoccupation with validation from others, envy, and arrogance are consistent with narcissistic personality disorder. Narcissistic personality disorder is characterized by a life-long pattern of grandiosity, a need for external admiration, and limited empathy for others. The most useful feature in distinguishing narcissistic personality disorder from other cluster B disorders is the presence of grandiosity and inflated self-esteem. Patients with narcissistic personality disorder often have inflated but stable self-image and self-control.        

Narcissistic personality disorder is a Cluster B personality disorder; Cluster B also includes borderline, histrionic, and antisocial personality disorders. Unlike in patients with borderline personality disorder, patients with narcissistic personality disorder do not typically have self-destructive behaviors, impulsivity, separation insecurity, or emotional hyperreactivity. While patients with histrionic personality disorder also have attention-seeking behavior, patients with narcissistic personality disorder specifically seek attention to be admired. Narcissistic personality disorder does not include the impulsivity, aggression, and deceit seen in antisocial personality disorder.  

Option Analysis

✅ Narcissistic personality disorder :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with schizoid personality disorder are indifferent to the praise and criticism of others. This patient’s preoccupation with the perception of others is better explained by narcissistic personality disorder.  
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with borderline personality disorder may also feel a need to seek the attention of others. However, this patient’s stable self-image, lack of self-destructiveness, and lack of emotional hyperreactivity are more consistent with narcissistic personality disorder.  
❌ Antisocial personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with antisocial personality disorder can present with superficial attitudes and exploitative behavior. However, this patient’s grandiosity and need for external validation are more consistent with narcissistic personality disorder.  
❌ Histrionic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with histrionic personality disorder often seek the attention of others. However, this patient’s absence of exaggerated emotions, theatrical gestures, dramatic speech, and other findings are more consistent with narcissistic personality disorder.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry office because of intrusive thoughts for the past year. The patient feels compelled to complete tasks in repetitions of three (for example, locking the door three times before leaving for work). When resisting these compulsions, the patient experiences racing thoughts and difficulty focusing until they give in to the urge. These repetitive behaviors are worsening in frequency and result in being late to work daily. There is no significant past medical or psychiatric history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Mental status exam shows a euthymic adult who appears the stated age with no acute distress. Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive scale (Y-BOCS) score is 24. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with intrusive thoughts and compulsions likely has obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Given this patient’s Y-BOCS score is 24, they appear to have severe OCD. For severe OCD, combining cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) with medication is the preferred first-line treatment.

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a specific type of CBT that uses graded exposure to feared stimuli. For example, ERP might involve encouraging this patient to engage in their compulsions only twice instead of three times, with the goal of gradually reducing the behavior further.

Validated rating scales, such as the Y-BOCS, help quantify the level of impairment and guide recommended therapy options—including CBT, clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant), and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). A Y-BOCS score of 8-15 indicates mild OCD, 16-23 indicates moderate OCD, and a score of 24 or higher suggests severe OCD. Patients with mild OCD may be effectively managed with either medications or CBT alone, while moderate OCD may benefit from medications alone or in combination with CBT. In contrast, severe OCD generally requires a combined approach of CBT and medication. The Y-BOCS is also valuable for tracking treatment response. For instance, a patient whose Y-BOCS score improves from 24 to 4 after starting an SSRI and CBT demonstrates a significant reduction in symptoms.

Option Analysis

✅ Cognitive behavioral therapy plus clomipramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cognitive behavioral therapy alone:
Incorrect: Cognitive behavioral therapy is very effective in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). While it can be used alone in cases of mild OCD (Y-BOCS score of 8-15), this patient has severe OCD, which should also be treated with medication.
❌ Clomipramine alone:
Incorrect: Clomipramine is an effective medication for the treatment of OCD. However, as this patient has severe OCD, adding cognitive behavioral therapy to treatment is most appropriate.
❌ Lorazepam alone:
Incorrect: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is effective for the acute management of severe anxiety. However, it is not effective in the long-term treatment of OCD. Clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant) or a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) in conjunction with cognitive behavioral therapy is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Aripiprazole plus clomipramine:
Incorrect: Aripiprazole and similar second-generation antipsychotics are reasonable augmentation or second-line agents in treatment-resistant OCD. However, this patient has not yet tried first-line treatment options such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant) with cognitive behavioral therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old nonbinary person presents to the psychiatry office because of intrusive thoughts and compulsive handwashing for the past two years. The patient is currently taking fluvoxamine but has not experienced significant improvement in symptoms or changes in their Yale-Brown obsessive-compulsive score (Y-BOCS). A previous trial with fluoxetine provided minimal benefit. In addition to pharmacotherapy, the patient participates in exposure and response prevention therapy (ERP), which has provided only mild benefit. There is no significant medical history or other psychiatric history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The mental status exam reveals an anxious-appearing adult with meticulous grooming and hygiene. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and complete metabolic panel, are within normal limits, and a urinary drug screen is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in patient care?
questions.solution:
This patient’s two-year history of repetitive thoughts and compulsive handwashing is consistent with severe obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
