Incorrect: Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used as a first-line antidepressant medication. Although venlafaxine (another SNRI) has been shown to increase the QT interval, no significant association has been found with duloxetine.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation after a syncopal episode. The event occurred one hour prior to arrival after she stood up from the couch. It was witnessed by her partner, who reports loss of consciousness lasting a few seconds. She did not hit her head, and there was no seizure activity noted. During the past year, she has had several episodes of syncope that have increased in frequency. The patient has a history of anorexia nervosa, with prior outpatient treatment six months ago. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 39/min, respirations are 15/minute, blood pressure is 84/58 mmHg, and body mass index (BMI) is 15 kg/m2. The patient is dysphoric in effect, but able to cooperate and follow commands. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal other than bradycardia. Abdominal examination is normal. Lanugo is noted on the arms. Gait is unsteady, but the neurologic examination is otherwise within normal limits. Electrocardiogram shows sinus bradycardia without other abnormalities. Comprehensive metabolic panel is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Rapid high-caloric nutritional rehabilitation in the emergency department
Hospitalization with nutritional rehabilitation via nasogastric tube

questions.solution:
This patient’s anorexia nervosa and malnutrition has led to hemodynamic changes including bradycardia and hypotension. Given her repeated syncopal events and sustained bradycardia, inpatient care is the appropriate treatment setting. Nutritional rehabilitation should begin orally, typically at a gradual pace, although there is increasing evidence that a more rapid administration of calories may also be safe.

Patients with eating disorders who are experiencing severe symptoms or hemodynamic instability, including hypothermia, significant bradycardia, or hypotension, should be treated in the inpatient setting. Hospitalization allows for monitored nutritional rehabilitation and medical management of cardiac and metabolic complications.

Patients should be monitored for signs of refeeding syndrome, a dangerous metabolic imbalance caused by the reintroduction of food after a period of malnourishment; daily fluid intake and output should be documented, and electrolytes should be monitored and replaced. Nutritional rehabilitation is ideally done through oral intake of regular food with the goal of the patient gaining bodyweight. Nutritional rehabilitation via regular food is ideal as it can allow patients to re-establish eating patterns to allow for continued stability once discharged.

For patients extremely underweight patients (BMI <15kg/m2) or unable to eat enough food to gain weight, nasogastric tube feeding can be considered. It is important to note that the risk of refeeding syndrome may be greater in those receiving nasogastric tube feeding.  Intravenous total parenteral nutrition is a treatment of last resort when no alternative routes of nutritional rehabilitation are available. Total parenteral IV nutritional rehabilitation carries an elevated risk of catheter-related infections and air emboli. 

P.S. If you or someone you know is experiencing an eating disorder, you can call the ANAD National Eating Disorder Helpline at 800.375.7767 or visit https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/get-help/ to learn more about resources available in your area.     

Option Analysis

❌ Hospitalization with parenteral nutrition rehabilitation:
Incorrect: Parenteral nutritional rehabilitation may be necessary for patients experiencing anorexia nervosa who cannot tolerate oral nutrition sources. This patient should be initially started on oral nutrition, with escalation to nasogastric tube or parenteral nutrition only if needed.  
✅ Hospitalization with oral nutrition rehabilitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rapid high-caloric nutritional rehabilitation in the emergency department:
Incorrect: Rapid refeeding protocols have been investigated to help ease the total cost of hospitalization and length of stay of patients experiencing eating disorders. However, facilities use these protocols in the inpatient setting to allow for close monitoring to mitigate the risk of refeeding syndrome; administration in the emergency department is not appropriate. 
❌ Outpatient dietitian referral:
Incorrect: Collaborative interdisciplinary care, including with a dietitian is important in the treatment of patients experiencing eating disorders. However, outpatient management of eating disorders is best used for medically stable patients; this patient should be hospitalized given her repeated syncopal episodes and sustained bradycardia. 
❌ Hospitalization with nutritional rehabilitation via nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Nasogastric feeding is helpful in the inpatient management of patients experiencing eating disorders who are extremely ill or who have continued to lose weight despite oral refeeding efforts. This patient should undergo a trial of oral nutrition rehabilitation before considering a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the primary care office for evaluation of muscle cramping since his annual physical exam three months ago. He also reports generalized weakness. He does not note any relieving factors or provoking factors for either symptom. The patient has no history of medical or psychiatric conditions. He reports that he started a rigorous weight-lifting program about one year ago. The patient is calm with moments of irritability during this visit. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and body mass index (BMI) is 19.0 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows a thin young adult male, who is awake and alert and in no acute distress. Musculoskeletal exam shows increased muscle tone and more vascularity in his bilateral upper extremities relative to the previous visit three months prior. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Serum magnesium is 1.1 mEq/L, and serum phosphorous is 2.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Total testosterone and free testosterone levels

questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of muscle cramps and generalized weakness, along with the presence of hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia, are suggestive of nutritional deficiencies. The patient’s significant body fat loss over a brief period should raise suspicion for an eating disorder. In patients suspected of having an eating disorder, it is prudent to urgently obtain a complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, serum magnesium level, serum phosphorous level, urinalysis, and a 12-lead ECG. Obtaining an ECG is the next best step for this patient as cardiovascular complications are the most common cause of death in patients experiencing eating disorders, and he has electrolyte abnormalities. 

Performing these diagnostic measures allows clinicians to identify high-acuity complications linked to eating disorders. For example, ECG may show QT prolongation, arrhythmias, or cardiac abnormalities due to electrolyte deficiencies. Electrolyte levels may show deficiencies that need to be corrected. 

Supportive evidence that this patient is experiencing an eating disorder includes exam findings of increased muscle tone and vascularity which suggest this patient had a significant decrease in his body fat percentage over a brief period. Moreover, his BMI is in the low range. The patient’s symptoms of weakness, muscle cramps, and fatigue developed over the same duration of time as his weight loss, suggesting that aggressive dieting played a role in these nutritional deficiencies. 

P.S. If you or someone you know is experiencing an eating disorder, you can call the ANAD National Eating Disorder Helpline at 800.375.7767 or visit https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/get-help/ to learn more about resources available in your area.   

Option Analysis

✅ 12-Lead electrocardiogram (ECG) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Reassurance:
Incorrect: Reassurance is a helpful clinical tool that provides patients comfort and improves therapeutic rapport. However, this patient’s low magnesium and phosphorus levels indicate that further work-up with an ECG and further clinical history is needed.  
❌ Total testosterone and free testosterone levels:
Incorrect: Performance-enhancing drug use is an oft-ignored cause of medical complications in young adults who begin rigorous exercise programs. However, it is best to discuss such concerns with patients to maintain therapeutic rapport before obtaining a hormone panel. The patient’s reported symptoms of low magnesium and phosphorus levels and low BMI indicate that an ECG and further clinical history are needed. 
❌ Vitamin B12 level :
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency is important to consider in patients who present with symptoms of nutritional deficiency. However, as vitamin B12 deficiency takes several years to develop following dietary changes, it is unlikely in this patient who has changed his diet within the past 12 months.  
❌ Oral multivitamin prescription:
Incorrect: Multivitamins can help patients obtain nutritional requirements that may be difficult to obtain due to dietary restrictions or socio-cultural norms. However, this patient’s abnormal lab results and physical examination findings indicate the need for further diagnostic testing including ECG and further clinical history before making a diagnosis and beginning treatment.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for evaluation of new-onset skin flushing. She reports feeling warm and sweating overnight, and this morning noticed that her skin appeared red. She has a history of fibromyalgia and was recently diagnosed with premenstrual dysphoric disorder. She does not have any other medical conditions. The patient takes milnacipran for her fibromyalgia and yesterday she took an over-the-counter supplement recommended by a friend for her premenstrual symptoms. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations 20/minute, blood pressure is 142/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Diffuse erythema is noted on the skin. Neurological examination shows brisk reflexes in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Which of the following most likely caused this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient who is taking milnacipran has developed fever, tachycardia, hypertension, erythema diaphoresis, hyperreflexia, and agitation after starting an over-the-counter supplement. She most likely has serotonin syndrome from the use of milnacipran, which is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in combination with St. John’s wort which acts as a serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

While natural remedies often do not increase the risk of side effects, some supplements may lead to drug-drug interactions. St. John’s wort is an herbal supplement used for depression and premenstrual dysphoric syndrome; it can cause a potentially life-threatening increase in serotonergic activity known as serotonin syndrome when taken with other medications that also increase serotonergic activity in the central nervous system. 

Patients with Serotonin syndrome can present with a variety of findings, and the presentation can vary. Findings can include elevated body temperature, hypertension, muscle rigidity, tremor, hyperreflexia, and diaphoresis. In some patients, myoclonus may also be present. In severe cases, patients may develop seizures. Medication and dietary supplement interactions are a common cause of serotonin syndrome. It is prudent to include questions about dietary supplements as part of a complete medication history. Some antidepressants as well as other medications that may cause serotonin syndrome include cyclobenzaprine, dextromethorphan, linezolid, tramadol, and triptans. Recreational substances like methamphetamine, MDMA, and cocaine can also increase the risk of serotonin syndrome.       

Option Analysis

❌ Kava root :
Incorrect: Kava root is an herbal supplement taken to decrease anxiety and produce a calming effect by its anxiolytic properties. It does not have serotonergic effects. this patient is displaying signs of serotonin syndrome with findings of hyperreflexia, fever, diaphoresis, suggesting the use of an herb with serotonergic effects such as St. John’s wort. 
✅ St. John’s wort :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Red yeast rice:
Incorrect: Potential side effects of red yeast rice include gastrointestinal upset, muscle aches, headaches, dizziness, and liver damage. This patient is presenting with features concerning for serotonin syndrome, and a supplement that increases serotonergic activity in the central nervous system, such as St. John’s wort, is likely to have caused the condition.   
❌ Phenibut:
Incorrect: Phenibut acts as a GABA-B agonist. It does not have significant serotonin activity and would not cause this patient’s symptoms of serotonin syndrome.  
❌ Yerba santa:
Incorrect: Yerba santa is an herbal supplement used for respiratory symptoms. It does not have serotoninergic activity and would not cause this patient’s symptoms of serotonin syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his psychiatrist’s office for a follow-up appointment. He reports a fine tremor in his right hand when writing that has been present for the last two weeks. The patient has a history of bipolar 1 disorder and began taking lithium one month ago. There have been no changes in his medical history since his last appointment. He does not use alcohol or other recreational substances. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 18/minute, blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, and body mass index (BMI) is 22 kg/m². On physical examination, the patient is comfortable and not in distress. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits, and neurological examination shows a subtle, fine tremor in the bilateral upper extremities when the arms are extended during the Romberg test. The musculoskeletal exam is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue lithium and schedule close follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient has developed a postural tremor after starting lithium for bipolar I disorder. Tremor is a commonly recognized side effect of lithium. Given this patient’s recent initiation of lithium, a lithium level should be performed to rule out toxicity as the first step in management.

Postural tremor occurs when a body part is held against gravity, such as an upper extremity tremor that increases in severity when a patient maintains the arm outstretched from the body. Postural tremors can occur with lithium therapy, even in therapeutic ranges. However, it can also indicate lithium toxicity, so obtaining a lithium level can help guide dose adjustments. If the lithium level is therapeutic, and there are no indications of an alternate cause of the tremor, the most likely diagnosis is a lithium-induced postural tremor. Other medications that may cause postural tremor include antiepileptics, antidepressants, stimulants, and substances like caffeine.    

Option Analysis

✅ Check lithium level :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Order urine drug screen:
Incorrect: Urine drug screens are useful for determining if observed symptoms are related to acute substance intoxication or substance withdrawal. However, this patient’s use of lithium indicates that testing the lithium level is more appropriate.  
❌ Provide reassurance:
Incorrect: Reassurance is a crucial part of managing patients with medication side effects that are transient and self-limited. However, this patient’s use of lithium and the presence of new neurological symptoms indicates that further testing of the lithium level is warranted.  
❌ Order electromyography:
Incorrect: Electromyography (EMG) can help diagnose symptoms related to abnormal neuronal activity. However, checking lithium level is a less invasive and less expensive test that may identify the cause of this patient’s symptoms. 
❌ Discontinue lithium and schedule close follow-up:
Incorrect: Discontinuation of the medication may be necessary in some cases of lithium-induced tremor that cannot be controlled with medical management; however, there are conservative measures that can be tried first.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the psychiatry clinic for a 3-month history of muscle stiffness. He started on haloperidol 3 months ago for the treatment of hallucinations and paranoia. Although his psychiatric symptoms are now in remission, he finds the muscle stiffness intolerable. His temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Musculoskeletal exam reveals bilateral rigidity in the upper extremities during both flexion and extension. The mental status exam shows a calm, well-groomed male who appears his stated age. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count (CBC) and comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), are within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to reduce the future risk of this adverse drug effect?
questions.solution:
This 27-year-old patient, who is experiencing severe, intolerable muscle stiffness while taking haloperidol, is likely suffering from extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS). When managing side effects from antipsychotics, it is important to first assess their severity. Mild muscle stiffness may improve with adjunctive oral anticholinergic therapy, such as benztropine or trihexyphenidyl. However, in patients with severe EPS, the most appropriate step to reduce the risk of recurrence is to switch to an antipsychotic with a lower propensity for these effects, such as quetiapine.        

Among the available antipsychotics, quetiapine and clozapine are favorable options for patients experiencing severe EPS due to their minimal risk of inducing these symptoms. In contrast, first-generation antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) carry an elevated risk of EPS. Among second-generation antipsychotics, risperidone is associated with a higher risk of EPS compared to other agents in its class — though still lower than that observed with first-generation antipsychotics.       

Beyond differences in EPS risk, first-generation and second-generation antipsychotics also vary in their other side effect profiles. First-generation antipsychotics are more likely to cause anticholinergic side effects, whereas second-generation agents tend to be associated with metabolic side effects, including increased plasma lipids, elevated blood glucose, and a higher risk of weight gain and type 2 diabetes.   

Option Analysis

❌  Intramuscular benztropine :
Incorrect: While intramuscular benztropine can provide rapid relief of severe extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), it only addresses the symptoms rather than reducing the future risk of EPS. Switching to a second-generation antipsychotic with lower EPS potential is typically more effective in preventing future episodes.  
❌ Reassurance:
Incorrect: While reassurance may be considered for mild or self-limiting side effects, this patient finds the muscle stiffness intolerable. Reassurance alone would be insufficient in preventing or managing his current symptoms.  
✅ Cross-titration to quetiapine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cross-titration to fluphenazine :
Incorrect: Both fluphenazine and haloperidol are first-generation antipsychotics, which carry a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms compared to a second-generation antipsychotic, such as quetiapine.  
❌ Oral benztropine :
Incorrect: Oral benztropine is useful for managing mild extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), but it does not reduce the risk of recurrence. Because these symptoms are severe, switching to an alternative antipsychotic is the most effective way to reduce this patient’s future risk of EPS.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the primary care office with a 4-month history of difficulty sleeping. She completed basic military training 3 months ago and is living at home prior to deployment. She experiences frequent nightmares, night sweats, mood lability, and poor motivation. She often avoids going to bed because falling asleep is challenging. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. On mental status examination, she appears her stated age and demonstrates appropriate grooming and hygiene. Which of the following additional findings would support the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with four months of poor sleep, nightmares, frequent awakenings, mood lability, and poor motivation for four months — symptoms that raise concern for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Basic training can be highly stressful and, for some enlistees, may trigger traumatic responses due to its intense physical and psychological demands. Of the findings listed, only a constricted affect is associated with a stress-related disorder like PTSD.

Emotional numbing is a key symptom of PTSD and is categorized under negative alterations in cognitions and mood category. A reduced ability to express emotion reflects the impact of traumatic experiences and may persist as a chronic symptom or emerge in response to distressing memories or flashbacks. Additional features of PTSD include hypervigilance, trauma avoidance, and intrusive thoughts.

Option Analysis

✅ Constricted affect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Angor animi:
Incorrect: Angor animi, or Gairdner disease, refers to a feeling of “impending doom” and is typically associated with certain medical conditions such as acute coronary syndrome or pheochromocytoma. It is not included in the diagnostic criteria for post-traumatic stress disorder.
❌ Hyperphagia:
Incorrect: Hyperphagia, or increased food intake, is a symptom of major depressive disorder with atypical features. However, this patient’s symptoms—poor sleep, nightmares, frequent awakenings, mood lability, and anhedonia—are more consistent with post-traumatic stress disorder.
❌ Paranoia and auditory hallucinations:
Incorrect: Paranoia and auditory hallucinations are characteristic of a psychotic disorder. While post-traumatic stress disorder can include hypervigilance and some dissociative symptoms, true paranoia and persistent hallucinations are not typical features.
❌ Recurrent fear of contamination:
Incorrect: A recurrent fear of contamination can be experienced by patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder. Although patients with post-traumatic stress disorder may experience intrusive thoughts related to a traumatic event, they do not result in a recurrent fear of contamination or compulsive behaviors.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a rash that has been present for the past three weeks. The patient reports that the rash occasionally bleeds and is also itchy. Recently, the patient began volunteering at a veterinary clinic and is anxious about exposure to “bugs and things” at work. The patient finds that handwashing or showering relieves this anxiety, although these behaviors have led to tardiness at school and work on several occasions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Dermatological exam shows erythematous, pruritic dermatitis with lichenification on the extensor surfaces of both hands. The mental status exam reveals an anxious individual with carefully maintained grooming and hygiene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of intrusive thoughts, ritualistic handwashing and bathing, and functional impairment are consistent with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

Patients with OCD often come to clinical attention after starting new careers or hobbies, such as volunteering at a veterinary clinic in this case. When considering a diagnosis of OCD, it is important to gather information about functional impairment; for example, this patient arrives late for school and work due to these symptoms. A key detail that helps distinguish OCD from other anxiety disorders is the presence of repetitive behaviors that lead to a reduction in anxiety, as seen when this patient experiences less anxiety after repeatedly washing their hands. A helpful clinical pearl for patients with contamination-subtype OCD is to look for a bilateral erythematous hand rash caused by the abrasion from frequent handwashing, as described in this vignette.

Option Analysis

✅ Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD):
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder shares some features with OCD. However, these individuals are often unaware of their behaviors and do not experience the same level of distress. In contrast, this patient’s insight and distress about their compulsions favor a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
❌ Specific phobia :
Incorrect: Patients with specific phobias can exhibit fear of contamination or infection. However, the presence of compulsive handwashing that relieves anxiety is more indicative of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder should be considered when patients present with a chief complaint of anxiety and is characterized by pervasive and excessive worry about various aspects of life. However, this patient’s specific intrusive thoughts and the relief provided by repetitive behaviors are more consistent with obsessive-compulsive disorder.
❌ Adjustment disorder:
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder should be considered in patients reporting psychiatric symptoms after experiencing life changes. However, this patient’s obsessive thoughts, compulsions, and functional impairment align more closely with obsessive-compulsive disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the psychiatry clinic because of interpersonal difficulties for the past year. He frequently argues with his partner and coworkers, who describe him as controlling and critical. The patient is often late completing work due to spending excessive time organizing his desk and rechecking tasks, and he becomes distressed when others do not follow the procedure. The patient is not concerned about these behaviors or tendencies and states, “Everyone else is wrong.” Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/66 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Mental status exam shows a well-groomed individual with appropriate affect and carefully maintained clothing and hygiene. Laboratory studies (complete blood count (CBC), complete metabolic panel (CMP), and urinary drug screen) are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 25-year-old patient’s pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, control, and perfectionism for over a year, leading to social impairment, is most suggestive of obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD).         

OCPD is classically associated with ego-syntonic (derived from the Greek synton, meaning harmony or synergy) symptoms, meaning individuals do not find these thoughts or behaviors distressing. Because these symptoms are not bothersome, patients often come to clinical attention only due to observations from their peers.        

The ego-syntonic tendencies of OCPD contrast with the ego-dystonic symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), in which patients experience significant discomfort and distress from obsessive thoughts and compulsions. Although both OCPD and avoidant personality disorder can lead to social impairment, in OCPD the impairment stems from a rigid need for control rather than the fear of judgement or rejection. Compared with dependent personality disorder, patients with OCPD tend to be controlling, perfectionist, and autonomous.    

Option Analysis

✅ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obsessive-compulsive disorder  :
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive disorder is defined by ego-dystonic, intrusive, distressing obsessions and repetitive compulsions performed to relieve anxiety. However, because this patient is not distressed by their tendencies, and these behaviors and thoughts are ego-syntonic, obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Avoidant personality disorder :
Incorrect: Patients with avoidant personality disorder experience marked social impairment due to fear of rejection and feelings of inadequacy. While this patient has interpersonal conflicts, they stem from a rigid need for control rather than fear of rejection or negative perception, making obsessive-compulsive personality disorder the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Dependent personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with dependent personality disorder excessively rely on others and find it difficult to make decisions without reassurance. They may also experience fear of separation or abandonment. However, this patient’s controlling nature, perfectionistic tendencies, and autonomous nature are most consistent with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder. 
❌ Adjustment disorder :
Incorrect: Patients with adjustment disorder may experience a myriad of psychiatric symptoms, including perfectionism or a fixation on high-quality work, especially with starting new jobs, educational pursuits, or other life changes. However, this patient’s pervasive pattern of perfectionism, need for control, and distress when their perceived order is disrupted is more consistent with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for an annual physical examination for volleyball. During the interview, the patient mentions that she keeps a quartz crystal in her uniform to ensure the team wins each game. The patient shares that a fairy godmother indicates which plays to make on the court by sending electrical signals down her spine. These beliefs have led to isolation from teammates, with most of her time spent with family. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. A mental status exam reveals a pleasant age-apparent adolescent wearing odd clothing and with a restricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.solution:
This 18-year-old patient’s social impairment, magical thinking, odd appearance, unusual perceptual experiences, and restricted range of affect are most suggestive of schizotypal personality disorder.        

Schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder that causes a life-long pattern of social deficits (including lack of close friends and/or social anxiety), cognitive or perceptual disturbances, and eccentric behavior and appearance that are outside the cultural and religious norms of the individual. According to the DSM-5, the diagnosis requires five or more characteristic features with an onset by early adulthood.       

Much like other cluster A personality disorders, patients with schizotypal personality disorder often experience interpersonal and social deficits due to the disorder. However, the presence of magical thinking and odd behaviors is an important distinguishing characteristic when compared to schizoid personality disorder or paranoid personality disorder. As with other personality disorders, it is essential to first rule out primary schizophrenia spectrum disorders or mood disorders with psychotic features before making this diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

❌ Schizoid personality disorder :
Incorrect: Patients with schizoid personality disorder have limited interest in interpersonal relationships and prefer being alone. However, this patient’s odd behavior, magical thinking, and unusual clothing are more consistent with schizotypal personality disorder.  
✅ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Paranoid personality disorder :
Incorrect: Patients with paranoid personality disorder experience paranoia that limits social interactions. However, this patient’s social functioning is impacted by unusual beliefs and behavior rather than paranoia, making schizotypal personality disorder a more appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Major depressive disorder with psychotic features:
Incorrect: While patients with major depressive disorder with psychotic features may have delusions, this patient does not present with symptoms of depression. The unusual beliefs and magical thinking are better explained by schizotypal personality disorder. 
❌ Delusional disorder :
Incorrect: Patients with delusional disorder may have supernatural delusions, but their social functioning is not typically severely impaired. The impaired social functioning, odd behavior, unusual clothing, and magical thinking observed with this patient are more consistent with schizotypal personality disorder.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the psychiatry clinic because of a depressed mood for the past 3 years. The patient cannot recall the last time he felt happy and describes himself as a pessimist by nature. The patient endorses low self-esteem, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and struggles to find motivation to perform well at work. There are no suicidal thoughts or a history of suicidal thoughts or attempts. The patient cannot identify any times during the past 3 years when symptoms improved, even for brief periods. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/76 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Mental status exam shows a disheveled adult with a depressed affect, normal speech, and linear and logical thought processes. Recent complete blood count (CBC), vitamin B12, comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), and thyroid panel are normal. Which element of the patient’s history is most specific for persistent depressive disorder (PDD)?
questions.solution:
This adult patient presents with a 3-year history of anhedonia, depressed mood, low energy, poor self-esteem, and difficulty concentrating; these symptoms are consistent with persistent depressive disorder (PDD). To meet criteria for PDD, patients must exhibit a persistently depressed mood and at least 2 additional symptoms of depression over at least 2 years, without relief in symptoms for greater than 2 months in that time period.        

PDD can be distinguished from major depressive disorder (MDD) by their diagnostic criteria. MDD requires a persistently depressed mood and at least 4 additional symptoms over at least 2 weeks.        

While PDD is a distinct diagnosis from MDD, patients with the disorder may also experience an acute episode of MDD. Such cases are informally referred to as “double depression” and are associated with more difficult-to-treat depression and poorer outcomes.        

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

✅ Symptom duration :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Occupational functioning:
Incorrect: While depressive disorders often lead to impairment in daily functioning (including occupational, social, or academic settings), this is not specific to PDD. The patient’s duration of symptoms is the key differentiating factor.  
❌ Suicidal ideation or attempts:
Incorrect: While the absence of suicidal ideation or attempts is a positive predictor of recovery from depression, it is not included in the diagnostic criteria for PDD. The patient’s duration of depressive symptoms is the key differentiating factor. 
❌ Interest in activities :
Incorrect: A reduced interest in activities (anhedonia) is a common symptom across several depressive disorders. Therefore, it is not specific to the diagnosis of PDD. This patient’s duration of symptoms is the key differentiating factor. 
❌ Alexithymia:
Incorrect: Difficulty identifying or expressing emotions (alexithymia) can occur in depression, but it is not a diagnostic feature of PDD. The patient’s duration of depressive symptoms is the key differentiating factor.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with low mood, poor energy, and difficulty concentrating for the past four months. The patient has lost interest in his hobbies and often sleeps past his alarm in the mornings, which has interfered with his work schedule. The patient does not have suicidal thoughts or a history of suicide attempts. There is no significant medical history, and the patient does not use alcohol or recreational substances. The patient reports a recent breakup with a significant other as a stressor and has felt more isolated than usual lately. The patient requests the most effective treatment regardless of the cost. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Mental status exam reveals a calm adult with a flat affect, slowed speech, and limited eye contact. Thought processes are linear and logical. PHQ-9 score is 14. Recent complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), and thyroid panel are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s poor sleep, depressed mood, impaired energy and concentration, and anhedonia suggest major depressive disorder (MDD), and the PHQ-9 score of 14 combined with impaired daily functioning indicates moderate MDD. The most evidence-based intervention for moderate MDD is a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), like fluoxetine, are first-line options when using a combined approach.        

When feasible, both treatment options should be initiated together, as this is the most effective intervention. Serotonin-norepinephrine uptake inhibitors (SNRIs) can be used in place of the SSRIs, especially if a patient fails to respond to or does not tolerate at least two therapeutic trials of an SSRI. SNRIs can be considered in patients with comorbid chronic pain since they also have efficacy in treating pain.        

Combination therapy may not always be possible due to patient preference, financial constraints, geographical availability, or limited access to psychotherapy or medication management. When used independently, psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy have similar effectiveness, so the intervention of choice should align with patient preference and lifestyle.        

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   



Option Analysis

✅ Fluoxetine and cognitive-behavioral therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fluoxetine :
Incorrect: Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is an effective first-line treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD). However, the most effective approach to treating moderate MDD is a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy.  
❌ Interpersonal psychotherapy:
Incorrect: Interpersonal psychotherapy is a useful therapeutic modality for patients with symptoms of depression. While this patient meets criteria for moderate major depressive disorder (MDD), the most effective intervention is a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy.  
❌ Bupropion:
Incorrect: Bupropion is an effective atypical antidepressant that can be used in patients who fail to respond to a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). However, while this patient does have symptoms of moderate major depressive disorder (MDD), the most appropriate next step in management is a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy.  
❌ Venlafaxine :
Incorrect: Venlafaxine is an effective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used in the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD). While this patient has symptoms of moderate MDD, the most effective approach is a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for a 3-hour history of agitation and chest discomfort. The patient was found pacing and shouting at home by a friend, who reports that the patient had “taken a bunch of something at a party to stay awake.” There is no known medical history. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 162/98 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals tachycardia. Mental status exam shows hypervigilance, pressured speech, and persecutory delusions. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with a QTc of 480 ms. Urine drug screen is positive for amphetamines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Rapid cooling with ice water immersion

questions.solution:
This 29-year-old patient presenting with agitation, hypervigilance, paranoia, tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia is likely experiencing acute stimulant intoxication. The first step in management of acute agitation and autonomic instability due to stimulant toxicity is benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam.        

When a patient presents with suspected stimulant use, perform an ABCDE assessment to evaluate stability. If unstable, stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation, which may involve supplemental oxygen or intubation. Obtain IV access and consider IV fluids, particularly if there are signs of hypovolemia. Continuous monitoring of vital signs, including temperature and cardiac telemetry, is essential. Cooling measures like cooling blankets should be used for hyperthermia (typically when temperature exceeds 40°C).    

The management of stimulant overdose is primarily supportive, including blood pressure control, sedation for psychosis or agitation, and evaluating for end-organ damage.        

Benzodiazepines mitigate the toxic effects of catecholamine excess caused by recreational stimulants by dampening the excessive central nervous system stimulation and sympathetic outflow caused by excessive doses of stimulants. This leads to reduced agitation, reduced blood pressure and heart rate, and reduced risk of rhabdomyolysis.     While haloperidol can be used in the management of psychosis related to stimulant intoxication, it is not the first-line treatment due to its potential to both prolong the QT interval and lower the seizure threshold, both of which are risky when managing stimulant toxicity.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intramuscular (IM) haloperidol :
Incorrect: Haloperidol is an effective intervention for acute agitation. However, in cases of potential stimulant overdose, benzodiazepines like lorazepam are preferred over antipsychotics due to the potential of antipsychotics to exacerbate QTc prolongation and decrease the seizure threshold. 
✅ Intravenous (IV) lorazepam  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rapid cooling with ice water immersion:
Incorrect: Rapid cooling with ice water immersion is used in the management of severe hyperthermia (typically when temperature exceeds 40°C). While this patient’s temperature is elevated, it has not reached the threshold for aggressive cooling. Benzodiazepines like lorazepam can normalize body temperature by minimizing the effects stimulants have on the sympathetic nervous system. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol, a nonselective beta blocker, is contraindicated in potential stimulant intoxication because it may cause unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, worsening hyperthermia and possibly leading to coronary vasospasm. Given these risks, benzodiazepines like lorazepam are the most appropriate next step in management.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) fluids with sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: IV fluids may be appropriate in cases of stimulant intoxication and associated hypovolemia. However, isotonic saline is typically preferred. Fluids with sodium bicarbonate may be considered if there is severe metabolic acidosis, significant QRS widening, or to alkalinize the urine in cases of rhabdomyolysis. Currently, none of these indications are present. Given the patient's severe agitation, a benzodiazepine such as lorazepam would be the most appropriate next step in management.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with 8 months of abdominal pain. The patient describes persistent, sharp pain that worsens after eating. The patient has been evaluated by multiple specialists, undergone several imaging studies, and tried various dietary modifications without relief. He is frustrated that he has not yet received an explanation for this pain. He reports anxiety only when thinking about the pain and has not experienced excessive worry about other aspects of life. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Mental status examination reveals a frustrated individual with restricted affect and linear and logical thought processes. Complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and abdominal ultrasound are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has endured persistent abdominal pain without an identifiable cause for eight months and is likely experiencing somatic symptom disorder.        

In somatic symptom disorder, diagnostic evaluations and imaging studies are often unrevealing, yet the patient’s experience of the symptom is genuine and can cause significant distress and functional impairment. To meet criteria for somatic symptom disorder, patients must exhibit excessive worry or preoccupation of at least one physical symptom for at least six months.       

Illness anxiety disorder differs in that patients report excessive fear of having or developing a serious illness despite few or no physical symptoms. In contrast, functional neurological symptom disorder can be conceptualized as a form of somatic symptom disorder focusing specifically on neurological symptoms (e.g., functional seizures, tremor, paralysis, blindness) that are inconsistent with recognized neurological disease. It is also important to consider malingering, in which symptoms are intentionally exaggerated or fabricated for external gain.         

A helpful analogy for understanding somatic symptom disorder and functional neurological symptom disorder is that of a smartphone with a software malfunction. While the device may appear structurally sound and intact, it can still fail to function properly. Similarly, in these disorders, although the body appears structurally normal, the patient experiences real and disruptive symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ Somatic symptom disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Illness anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with illness anxiety disorder are preoccupied with having or acquiring a serious illness despite minimal or mild physical symptoms. Because this patient experiences clear abdominal pain, somatic symptom disorder is the most appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Functional neurological symptom disorder:
Incorrect: Functional neurological symptom disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms (e.g., tremor, seizures) that are inconsistent with known neurological disease. Because this condition concerns neurological symptoms, it does not account for this patient’s abdominal pain, which is better explained by somatic symptom disorder. 
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by persistent worry about a variety of topics for at least a six-month period. Although patients with anxiety disorders may be at risk of somatic symptom disorders, this patient’s anxiety is confined to a single physical symptom, which is more consistent with somatic symptom disorder.  
❌ Malingering:
Incorrect: Malingering involves the intentional fabrication of symptoms for external gain, such as avoiding work or manipulating legal proceedings. In this case, there is no clear evidence of external incentives motivating the patient’s behavior, and his distress appears genuine, suggesting that somatic symptom disorder is the most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry clinic with vision loss over the past eight months. The patient was referred to psychiatry by an ophthalmologist, who was unable to identify the cause of her symptoms. The electronic health record indicates that multiple imaging studies revealed no clear pathology. A lumbar puncture was normal. The patient reports complete blindness of the left eye and no other neurological or systemic symptoms. When asked about recent stressors, the patient reports being held at gunpoint during a car theft eight months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/68 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Neurological exam shows no cranial nerve deficits, and tearing reflex is present bilaterally. Mental status exam reveals an anxious adult with normal eye contact and appropriate grooming and hygiene. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and thyroid studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with visual loss without structural abnormalities and a recent trauma is likely experiencing functional neurological symptom disorder. She meets the DSM-5 TR criteria for functional neurological symptom disorder due to significant distress regarding her vision for at least a six-month period.        

Functional visual disturbance is a common presenting symptom of functional neurological symptom disorder, affecting about 16% of patients with the disorder. A thorough physical exam is helpful when considering a diagnosis of functional blindness or functional visual impairment. A useful clinical pearl for assessing functional blindness is checking the tearing reflex, which refers to tear production when the eyes are exposed to a bright light. Since this reflex requires intact visual pathways, blindness with an intact tearing reflex suggests functional blindness.       

Functional neurological symptom disorder can be conceptualized as a subtype of somatic symptom disorder focusing on neurological symptoms. It differs from illness anxiety disorder, where patients often have no physical symptoms. An important differential diagnosis is malingering, where patients may misreport or exaggerate symptoms for external gain.    

Option Analysis

✅ Functional neurological symptom disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD):
Incorrect: PTSD is a common comorbid diagnosis in patients with functional neurological symptom disorder. However, this patient’s significant distress regarding their vision, without a clear etiology, and the absence of other symptoms typically associated with trauma disorders (e.g., flashbacks, hypervigilance, avoidance) suggest that functional neurological symptom disorder is the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Illness anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Illness anxiety disorder is characterized by severe anxiety or concern about having or developing a medical illness, often with few or no physical symptoms. Since this patient is experiencing visual impairment, functional neurological symptom disorder is the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder:
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by significant distress or functional impairment due to at least one physical symptom without a clear pathological cause. However, since this patient is specifically experiencing a neurologic symptom, functional neurological symptom disorder is the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Acute stress disorder :
Incorrect: Acute stress disorder occurs within one month of a traumatic event and involves dissociation, intrusive symptoms, and marked anxiety. This patient’s visual symptoms have persisted for eight months, and the presentation lacks the full symptom profile of acute stress disorder. Functional neurological symptom disorder remains the most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic because of difficulty sitting still for the past 4 months. Parents report the child often forgets his lunch bag at school, interrupts others during conversations, and “climbs everything.” The school has informed the family of similar concerns. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 99/50 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Mental status exam shows a child who is intermittently fidgety but otherwise euthymic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Follow up within the next 2 months

questions.solution:
This 8-year-old patient’s restless behavior, poor concentration, forgetfulness, tendency to interrupt others, and hyperactivity are consistent with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The DSM-5 requires at least six symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity to be present in two or more settings for at least six months. Because this patient’s symptoms have only been present for four months, the most appropriate next step is close follow-up to determine whether the duration criterion is met. Given that the symptoms occur throughout the day and there is no evidence of impaired communication, fixed interests, or rigid routines, ADHD remains the most likely diagnosis if symptoms persist at the next evaluation.

Symptoms of ADHD are often noted at home, at school, or during extracurricular activities. Gathering information from family, teachers, and supervisors using validated rating scales such as the Vanderbilt ADHD Diagnostic Rating Scale helps document symptom presence and severity across settings. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, treatment options in younger children can include psychotherapy, stimulant medications, or non-stimulant medications.

When considering a diagnosis of ADHD, it is prudent to also assess patients for difficulty with social communication, restricted interests, and rigid adherence to routine, since autism spectrum disorder frequently co-occurs. If symptoms are limited to a specific class or subject, a specific learning disorder should also be considered, especially if symptoms resolve with subjects the patient prefers or does well in.

Option Analysis

✅ Follow up within the next 2 months:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Psychotherapy:
Incorrect: Psychotherapy can be used in the management of pediatric attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, since this patient’s symptoms have not yet persisted for six months, close follow-up is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Methylphenidate :
Incorrect: Methylphenidate is a stimulant medication and the first-line choice in the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, because this patient’s symptoms have not yet persisted for six months, scheduling close follow-up is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Mixed amphetamine salts:
Incorrect: Mixed amphetamine salts are a first-line pharmacological option for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, since this child’s symptoms have not yet persisted for six months, scheduling close follow-up is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Guanfacine:
Incorrect: Guanfacine is an alpha-2a agonist medication that can be used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) when stimulants are contraindicated or when families prefer a non-stimulant option. However, because this child’s symptoms have not yet persisted for six months, scheduling close follow-up is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the psychiatry clinic for a 13-month history of frequent involuntary movements and vocalizations. Caregivers describe repeated eye blinking, facial grimacing, and grunting. These behaviors worsen when he is nervous or excited. The patient is aware of these concerns and feels an urge to act on them before the symptoms occur. Teachers have observed similar behaviors but note that concentration, grades, and social interactions remain excellent. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Mental status examination shows a well-appearing child in no acute distress. Complete blood count (CBC), complete metabolic panel (CMP), and thyroid studies are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 9-year-old patient’s repetitive involuntary motor behaviors and vocalizations for the past 13 months are highly suggestive of Tourette’s disorder. The diagnosis requires the presence of multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic for at least one year. Tic frequency often waxes and wanes over time.

Academic performance is a useful metric to differentiate Tourette’s disorder from conditions such as intellectual disability, specific learning disorders, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), since Tourette’s is not inherently associated with poor academic performance. Patients with Tourette’s disorder will not display the social communication deficits expected with ASD or pragmatic communication disorder. Additionally, although tics may be disruptive in work or school settings, Tourette’s disorder does not include symptoms of hyperactivity-impulsivity or inattention characteristic of ADHD. Finally, it is not associated with the poor impulse control or defiance that would be expected with conditions like oppositional defiant disorder.

It is important to recognize that Tourette’s disorder frequently co-occurs with other psychiatric conditions, most notably ADHD, disruptive behavior disorders, ASD, and impulse control disorders.

Option Analysis

❌ Autism spectrum disorder (ASD):
Incorrect: Although ASD carries an increased risk for developing Tourette’s or other tic-based disorders, this patient shows no deficits in social communication or interactions required for an ASD diagnosis.
✅ Tourette’s disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD):
Incorrect: Patients with ADHD are at an elevated risk for developing Tourette’s or tic-based disorders. However, this patient lacks the pervasive inattention, hyperactivity, or impulsivity across settings that characterize ADHD.
❌ Stereotypic movement disorder:
Incorrect: Stereotypic movement disorder typically begins by age 3 and is characterized by repetitive, purposeless motor behavior that interferes with social and academic functioning. Because this patient also exhibits involuntary verbal tics in addition to motor tics, Tourette’s disorder is the more likely diagnosis.
❌ Intellectual disability:
Incorrect: Intellectual disability can co-occur with conditions such as stereotypic movement disorder, Tourette’s disorder, and other communication disorders. However, this patient’s involuntary motor and vocal tics, together with preserved academic performance, point to Tourette’s disorder.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the psychiatric clinic due to severe distress over the past eight months regarding an upcoming family wedding. The patient feels paralyzed when thinking about giving a speech at the event and has considered skipping the wedding altogether. The patient worries about “saying something stupid” or being judged. She has also experienced anxiety when asked to give speeches at work. There is no fear of flying, heights, animals, or blood. There is no other significant psychiatric or medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The mental status exam shows a cooperative adult with an anxious affect, normal speech, and appropriate grooming and hygiene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 28-year-old patient has an eight-month history of a severe, specific fear of public speaking; she is likely experiencing social anxiety disorder.

Specific phobias and social anxiety disorder are characterized by intense, irrational fear or anxiety triggered by a specific object, situation, or activity that poses no inherent danger. This heightened sense of fear or anxiety often causes significant distress, impacting daily life and function. Unlike other anxiety disorders, such as generalized anxiety disorder, the range of triggers that cause anxiety is typically much narrower. However, it is important to keep in mind that patients with specific phobia or social anxiety disorder are at elevated risk for a comorbid anxiety disorder.

Social anxiety disorder can be conceptualized as a form of specific phobia, with the primary fear centered around being negatively evaluated in a social situation. During the history gathering, patients often report active avoidance of the trigger, such as this individual considering skipping the wedding to avoid the anxiety-provoking situation. These avoidant tendencies and functional impairment are required symptoms for the diagnosis. Additionally, a lack of anxiety in other contexts strengthens the case for social anxiety disorder, as the fear is specifically tied to social evaluation rather than being more generalized.

Option Analysis

✅ Social anxiety disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Specific phobia:
Incorrect: Specific phobias involve an intense fear of specific triggers or stimuli. While this patient has a fear of public speaking, the fear centers on the possibility of being evaluated negatively, which is more consistent with social anxiety disorder.
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder involves marked distress and anxiety about multiple stressors. This patient’s anxiety is specifically related to being evaluated negatively in a social context, making social anxiety disorder the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Panic disorder:
Incorrect: Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and the intense fear of having additional panic attacks. This patient's anxiety is related to the fear of negative evaluation in a social scenario, making social anxiety disorder the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Agoraphobia:
Incorrect: Agoraphobia is marked by fear or anxiety in two or more situations, such as public transportation, open or enclosed spaces, standing in line or in a crowd, or being alone outside the home. This patient’s anxiety is focused on being negatively evaluated, which is more consistent with social anxiety disorder.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of bizarre behavior over the past two hours. Friends report that the patient acted strangely at a party after placing a sticker on his tongue. There is no significant medical, surgical, or psychiatric history. The patient uses marijuana occasionally. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 138/84 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Mental status exam shows disorganized speech, impaired attention, and responsiveness to internal stimuli. The patient reports talking to aliens prior to the interview. Urine drug screen is positive for tetrahydrocannabinol. Which of the following additional findings would support the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Dry mucus membranes and urinary retention

questions.solution:
This patient’s bizarre behavior, confusion, disorganized speech, impaired attention, and hallucinations following sublingual use of a “paper strip” are characteristic of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Physical examination findings often include mydriasis (pupil dilation) and synesthesia, which refers to altered sensory perceptions such as “hearing colors” or “seeing sounds.” LSD is typically taken orally or sublingually, often via blotter paper or gelatin tabs infused with microgram amounts due to its high lipophilicity and potency.

Although the urinary screen in this case is positive for tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the acute onset of perceptual changes, inappropriate behavior, and visual hallucinations are more consistent with LSD intoxication than cannabis. LSD does not typically cause the severe agitation or aggression associated with stimulants such as phencyclidine (PCP), cocaine, or amphetamines. However, it may lead to insomnia, restlessness, and heightened alertness. LSD lacks anticholinergic effects, distinguishing it from deliriogenic substances like datura. LSD intoxication typically lasts between 6-12 hours.

Option Analysis

✅ Mydriasis and synesthesia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Agitation and decreased pain perception:
Incorrect: Agitation and decreased pain perception are associated with phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. This patient’s presentation is more likely due to LSD, which is unlikely to cause these symptoms. Mydriasis and synesthesia are more characteristic of LSD intoxication.
❌ Vertical nystagmus:
Incorrect: Nystagmus occurs with phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to LSD, which is unlikely to cause vertical nystagmus. Mydriasis and synesthesia are more characteristic of LSD intoxication.
❌ Dry mucus membranes and urinary retention:
Incorrect: Dry mucus membranes and urinary retention are signs of anticholinergic toxicity. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with LSD intoxication, which does not exert anticholinergic effects. Mydriasis and synesthesia are more suggestive of LSD intoxication.
❌ Ataxia and peripheral numbness:
Incorrect: Ataxia and peripheral numbness are characteristic of inhalant intoxication. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with LSD intoxication, which does not typically cause these symptoms. Mydriasis and synesthesia are more characteristic of LSD intoxication.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of agitation for the past four hours. The patient is accompanied by police officers and was found yelling obscenities in the parking lot of a grocery store. Upon arrival, the patient makes several violent gestures towards emergency department triage staff and subsequently requires multiple rounds of intramuscular lorazepam. Upon waking, the patient reports that the red colors in the ED room are “screaming at him.” Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 160/97 mmHg. Neurologic examination shows bilateral miosis and horizontal nystagmus. Mental status exam reveals an agitated adolescent who is difficult to comprehend. Labs and electrocardiogram cannot be obtained due to continued agitation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient shows signs of agitation, bilateral miosis, horizontal nystagmus, hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia, all of which suggest phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication.

PCP (also known as “angel dust,” “hog,” “elephant tranquilizer,” and “peace pill”) is a dissociative hallucinogen typically taken by mouth, snorted, or injected. Patients intoxicated with PCP often display erratic and violent behavior. They may also show increased pain tolerance, speech irregularities, memory deficits, and impulsive behavior. PCP can induce a temporary sensation of synesthesia, where sensory processing is altered, leading to experiences like “hearing colors” or “feeling sounds.” Intoxication can last anywhere from 6 to 48 hours.

PCP shares clinical features with recreational stimulants such as methamphetamine, cocaine, and amphetamine, including hypertension, tachycardia, and psychomotor agitation. However, rotary or horizontal nystagmus are more characteristic of PCP than cocaine, methamphetamine, or other hallucinogens (e.g., LSD, MDMA). Nystagmus can also occur with alcohol intoxication, but this does not typically cause severe agitation. The duration of intoxication with PCP is much longer than that of cocaine, and the best way to differentiate PCP intoxication from similar recreational substances is through a urine drug screen.

Option Analysis

✅ Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Methamphetamine intoxication:
Incorrect: Methamphetamine intoxication can cause tachycardia, hypertension, and bizarre behavior. However, nystagmus and synesthesia are more consistent with PCP intoxication.
❌ 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) intoxication:
Incorrect: MDMA intoxication can cause tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, and impulsive behavior. However, nystagmus is not typically observed in MDMA intoxication and is more suggestive of PCP intoxication.
❌ Cannabis intoxication:
Incorrect: Cannabis can cause bizarre behavior and sensory disturbances, but it does not typically cause violent behavior or severe agitation. These symptoms, along with synesthesia and nystagmus, are more consistent with PCP intoxication.
❌ Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication:
Incorrect: LSD can cause synesthesia, but it does not typically cause severe agitation, violent behavior, miosis, or nystagmus. The presentation in this case is more characteristic of PCP intoxication.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is transported by emergency medical services (EMS) to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home approximately one hour ago. The patient was discovered covered in emesis next to an empty prescription bottle for a medication used to treat generalized epilepsy. He typically takes clonazepam for epilepsy management, but he recently ran out of his medication. Temperature is 35.6°C (96°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 5/min, blood pressure is 100/56 mmHg, and Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is rated as 7. Mental status exam shows a pale young adult who appears to be his stated age and is minimally responsive to external stimuli. Shortly after arrival, the patient requires intubation and admission to the hospital. Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), complete blood count (CBC), and urine drug screen are pending. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
This 18-year-old patient with a history of epilepsy presents with unresponsiveness, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and respiratory depression consistent with acute benzodiazepine or barbiturate overdose. The clinical scenario describes a recent change in antiseizure medication following the discontinuation of clonazepam, making a barbiturate like primidone the most probable cause of this presentation among the choices provided.  

Barbiturates, while now less commonly used due to their narrow therapeutic index and elevated risk of fatal overdose, remain effective in the management of certain seizure disorders. In contrast to benzodiazepines, barbiturates can cause more profound central nervous system and respiratory depression, particularly in overdose. This is because barbiturates lack the ceiling effect seen with benzodiazepines, allowing for unchecked central nervous system (CNS) suppression at high doses.

Patients with a benzodiazepine or barbiturate overdose may present with coma, respiratory failure, bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia. A toxicology screen can help confirm the diagnosis, but supportive care should not be delayed while awaiting results. Prompt stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation is essential. Endotracheal intubation is indicated for patients with a Glasgow Coma Scale score less than 8 to protect the airway and ensure adequate ventilation.

Option Analysis

❌ Clonazepam:
Incorrect: While clonazepam overdose can cause sedation and respiratory depression in severe cases, the vignette suggests the patient does not currently have access to this medication. Also, due to a ceiling effect, benzodiazepines in isolation have a lower risk of severe respiratory depression relative to barbiturates. Of the available answer choices, primidone, a barbiturate used in the management of seizure disorder, is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
✅ Primidone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Carbamazepine :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine overdose typically causes anticholinergic effects such as dizziness, nystagmus, ataxia, and in severe cases, cardiac conduction abnormalities and seizures. Although it can contribute to altered mental status, it does not typically cause profound respiratory and CNS depression. Of the available answer choices, primidone, a barbiturate used in the management of seizure disorder, is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms.
❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine overdose is more commonly associated with symptoms of serotonin toxicity, including agitation, hyperreflexia, clonus, and hyperthermia. Severe sedation and respiratory depression are uncommon with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) alone. Of the available answer choices, primidone, a barbiturate used in the management of seizure disorder, is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms.
❌ Fluvoxamine:
Incorrect: Fluvoxamine is a selective-serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is FDA-approved for obsessive-compulsive disorder. An overdose of this medication is more commonly associated with symptoms of serotonin toxicity, including agitation, hyperreflexia, clonus, and hyperthermia. Severe sedation and respiratory depression are uncommon with SSRIs alone. Of the available answer choices, primidone, a barbiturate used in the management of seizure disorder, is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic due to frequent episodes of stress and chest discomfort over the past four months. These episodes occur unexpectedly and are accompanied by palpitations, shortness of breath, sweating, and a fear of “going crazy.” The patient expresses pervasive fear of having one of these episodes, leading to avoidance of places where they have occurred in the past, such as the mall and certain restaurants. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Mental status exam shows an anxious but pleasant adult with a blunted range of affect. Basic laboratory studies, including complete blood count, echocardiogram, comprehensive metabolic panel, and thyroid panel, are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s sudden-onset, untriggered episodes of severe anxiety, diaphoresis, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and palpitations are consistent with panic attacks. However, the hallmark symptom suggesting a diagnosis of panic disorder is the pervasive fear of experiencing future attacks.

While panic attacks can be part of the symptom clusters of most anxiety disorders included in the DSM, panic disorder specifically refers to impairment caused by persistent fear of having another panic attack. This contrasts with generalized anxiety disorder, which involves persistent anxiety regarding multiple sources of potential stress. A helpful fact to remember is that, with the exception of generalized anxiety disorder, anxiety disorders are defined by specific sources of anxiety. For instance, patients with specific phobia experience anxiety related to a fear of a particular object or situation, whereas those with social anxiety disorders experience anxiety related to social interactions.

Patients with panic disorder often make maladaptive behavioral changes to avoid triggering attacks, like steering clear of certain situations. An important symptom that often occurs with panic disorder is agoraphobia, which is characterized by anxiety in situations where escape might be difficult or where help may not be readily available, such as crowded events, enclosed areas, or being alone outside the home.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Panic disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by persistent, chronic anxiety about multiple subjects, often regarding finances, health, and interpersonal interactions. This patient’s symptoms—recurrent, unprovoked panic attacks and persistent worry about future episodes—are more consistent with panic disorder.
❌ Social anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Social anxiety disorder is characterized by anxiety regarding social interactions and negative evaluation by others. However, this patient’s episodes of severe anxiety without clear provoking factors are most likely panic attacks. The pervasive fear of having a panic attack suggests a diagnosis of panic disorder.
❌ Posttraumatic stress disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with posttraumatic stress disorder may experience anxiety exacerbations when exposed to triggers related to past trauma. However, this patient’s panic attacks, lack of trauma history, and pervasive fear of future panic attacks are more consistent with panic disorder.
❌ Specific phobia:
Incorrect: Specific phobia refers broadly to a class of disorders defined by pervasive, persistent fear of specific situations or objects (e.g., fear of heights, fear of spiders). However, this patient has panic attacks without a clear provoking factor and experiences persistent fear of panic attacks occurring in the future, making panic disorder the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the family medicine clinic because of severe muscle pain for the past year. While discussing this symptom, the patient reports significant stress related to finances, the cleanliness of his home and neighborhood, and the current geopolitical climate. The patient feels sweaty when discussing these concerns and reports feeling as though his mouth is numb. Sleep has been poor due to racing thoughts at night in addition to discomfort from the muscle pain. There is no past medical, psychiatric, or surgical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and neurological examinations are unremarkable. Mental status exam shows an anxious adult with appropriate grooming and hygiene. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and thyroid panel, are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s severe muscle tension, racing thoughts, stress, diaphoresis, and perioral numbness suggest an anxiety disorder. The patient’s report of persistent anxiety across multiple areas points to generalized anxiety disorder. His negative medical workup and physical exam support this diagnosis. Among the available answer choices, sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is the most appropriate management choice.

For anxiety causing functional impairment, a combination of psychotherapy and an SSRI (e.g., sertraline, fluoxetine, citalopram) is the most effective first-line treatment. If a combination approach is not feasible, either pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy alone are reasonable alternatives. Ultimately, the most effective treatment is the one a patient can adhere to long-term, as anxiety disorders typically require 6-8 weeks of treatment for noticeable improvements.

Alternative agents may include serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) or tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs). Buspirone or gabapentin can be considered if augmentation is needed. For severe anxiety attacks or exacerbations, short-term use of benzodiazepines or non-habit-forming alternatives like hydroxyzine can be useful.   

Option Analysis

✅ Sertraline :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Lorazepam can provide short-term relief for acute anxiety. However, benzodiazepines are not effective for long-term management. A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as sertraline, is the preferred first-line pharmacologic treatment for generalized anxiety disorder.
❌ Reassurance:
Incorrect: Reassurance is important for maintaining good therapeutic communication, but anxiety causing functional impairment should be treated. A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as sertraline, is a preferred first-line pharmacologic treatment for generalized anxiety disorder.
❌ Hydroxyzine:
Incorrect: Hydroxyzine, an antihistamine, may provide short-term relief of anxiety symptoms due to its sedative properties, but it is not effective for long-term management. A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as sertraline, is a preferred first-line pharmacologic treatment for generalized anxiety disorder.
❌ Electromyogram :
Incorrect: An electromyogram is useful when evaluating for neuromuscular disorders. However, this patient’s negative medical workup, normal neurological exam, and symptoms consistent with anxiety suggest an anxiety disorder. A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), like sertraline, is the most effective next step in management.
